title: Cleveland
text:
Cleveland ( ), officially the City of Cleveland, is a major city in the <a href="United%20States">U.S.</a> <a href="U.S.%20state">state</a> of <a href="Ohio">Ohio</a>, and the <a href="county%20seat">county seat</a> of <a href="Cuyahoga%20County%2C%20Ohio">Cuyahoga County</a>. It is located along the southern shore of <a href="Lake%20Erie">Lake Erie</a>, across the U.S. <a href="Canada%E2%80%93United%20States%20border">maritime border</a> with <a href="Canada">Canada</a> and approximately west of the Ohio-<a href="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a> state border.
The largest city on Lake Erie and one of the most populous urban areas in the country, Cleveland anchors the <a href="Greater%20Cleveland">Greater Cleveland Metropolitan Statistical Area</a> (MSA) and the <a href="Northeast%20Ohio">Cleveland–Akron–Canton Combined Statistical Area</a> (CSA). The CSA is the most populous <a href="combined%20statistical%20area">combined statistical area</a> in Ohio and the 17th largest in the United States, with a population of 3,633,962 in 2020. The city proper, with a 2020 population of 372,624, ranks as the <a href="List%20of%20United%20States%20cities%20by%20population">54th-largest city</a> in the U.S., as a larger portion of the metropolitan population lives outside the central city. The seven-county metropolitan Cleveland economy, which includes <a href="Akron%2C%20Ohio">Akron</a>, is the largest in the state.
Cleveland was founded in 1796 near the mouth of the <a href="Cuyahoga%20River">Cuyahoga River</a> by General <a href="Moses%20Cleaveland">Moses Cleaveland</a>, after whom the city was named. It grew into a major manufacturing center due to its location on both the river and the lake shore, as well as numerous canals and <a href="Rail%20transportation%20in%20the%20United%20States">railroad</a> lines. A <a href="Port%20of%20Cleveland">port city</a>, Cleveland is connected to the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> via the <a href="Saint%20Lawrence%20Seaway">Saint Lawrence Seaway</a>. The city's <a href="Economy%20of%20Greater%20Cleveland">economy</a> relies on diversified sectors such as manufacturing, financial services, <a href="Health%20care%20in%20the%20United%20States">healthcare</a>, biomedicals, and higher education. The gross domestic product (GDP) for the Greater Cleveland MSA was $135 billion in 2019. Combined with the <a href="Akron%20metropolitan%20area">Akron MSA</a>, the seven-county Cleveland–Akron metropolitan economy was $175 billion in 2019, the largest in Ohio, accounting for 25% of the state's GDP.
Designated as a "Gamma -" <a href="global%20city">global city</a> by the <a href="Globalization%20and%20World%20Cities%20Research%20Network">Globalization and World Cities Research Network</a>, the city's major cultural institutions include the <a href="Cleveland%20Museum%20of%20Art">Cleveland Museum of Art</a>, the <a href="Cleveland%20Museum%20of%20Natural%20History">Cleveland Museum of Natural History</a>, the <a href="Cleveland%20Orchestra">Cleveland Orchestra</a>, <a href="Playhouse%20Square">Playhouse Square</a>, and the <a href="Rock%20and%20Roll%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Rock and Roll Hall of Fame</a>. Known as "<a href="The%20Forest%20City">The Forest City</a>" among many other <a href="Nicknames%20of%20Cleveland">nicknames</a>, Cleveland serves as the center of the <a href="Cleveland%20Metroparks">Cleveland Metroparks</a> nature reserve system. The city's <a href="Major%20professional%20sports%20leagues%20in%20the%20United%20States%20and%20Canada">major league</a> <a href="Sports%20in%20Cleveland">professional sports teams</a> include the <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a>, the <a href="Cleveland%20Cavaliers">Cleveland Cavaliers</a>, and the <a href="Cleveland%20Guardians">Cleveland Guardians</a>.
History.
Establishment.
Cleveland was established on July 22, 1796, by surveyors of the <a href="Connecticut%20Land%20Company">Connecticut Land Company</a> when they laid out <a href="Connecticut">Connecticut</a>'s <a href="Connecticut%20Western%20Reserve">Western Reserve</a> into townships and a capital city. They named the new settlement "Cleaveland" after their leader, General <a href="Moses%20Cleaveland">Moses Cleaveland</a>. Cleaveland oversaw the <a href="New%20England">New England</a>-style design of the plan for what would become the modern downtown area, centered on <a href="Public%20Square%2C%20Cleveland">Public Square</a>, before returning home, never again to visit Ohio. The first permanent European settler in Cleaveland was <a href="Lorenzo%20Carter">Lorenzo Carter</a>, who built a cabin on the banks of the Cuyahoga River.
The settlement served as an important supply post for the U.S. during the <a href="Battle%20of%20Lake%20Erie">Battle of Lake Erie</a> in the <a href="War%20of%201812">War of 1812</a>. Locals adopted Commodore <a href="Oliver%20Hazard%20Perry">Oliver Hazard Perry</a> as a civic hero and erected a <a href="Perry%20Monument%20%28Cleveland%29">monument in his honor</a> decades later. The Village of Cleaveland was incorporated on December 23, 1814. In spite of the nearby swampy lowlands and harsh winters, the town's waterfront location proved to be an advantage, giving it access to Great Lakes trade. It grew rapidly after the 1832 completion of the <a href="Ohio%20and%20Erie%20Canal">Ohio and Erie Canal</a>. This key link between the <a href="Ohio%20River">Ohio River</a> and the <a href="Great%20Lakes">Great Lakes</a> connected it to the Atlantic Ocean via the <a href="Erie%20Canal">Erie Canal</a> and Hudson River, and later via the <a href="Saint%20Lawrence%20Seaway">Saint Lawrence Seaway</a>. Its products could reach markets on the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a> via the <a href="Mississippi%20River">Mississippi River</a>. The town's growth continued with added railroad links.
In 1831, the spelling of the town's name was altered by "The Cleveland Advertiser" newspaper. In order to fit the name on the newspaper's <a href="Nameplate%20%28publishing%29">masthead</a>, the editors dropped the first "a", reducing the city's name to "Cleveland", which eventually became the official spelling. In 1836, Cleveland, then only on the eastern banks of the Cuyahoga River, was officially incorporated as a city. That same year, it nearly erupted into open warfare with neighboring <a href="Ohio%20City%20%28Cuyahoga%20County%29%2C%20Ohio">Ohio City</a> over a bridge connecting the two communities. Ohio City remained an independent municipality until its <a href="Municipal%20annexation%20in%20the%20United%20States">annexation</a> by Cleveland in 1854.
Home to a vocal group of <a href="Abolitionism%20in%20the%20United%20States">abolitionists</a>, Cleveland (code-named "Station Hope") was a major stop on the <a href="Underground%20Railroad">Underground Railroad</a> for escaped <a href="African%20Americans">African American</a> <a href="Slavery%20in%20the%20United%20States">slaves</a> en route to <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. The city also served as an <a href="Cleveland%20in%20the%20American%20Civil%20War">important center</a> for the <a href="Union%20%28American%20Civil%20War%29">Union</a> during the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>. Decades later, in July 1894, the wartime contributions of those serving the Union from Cleveland and Cuyahoga County would be honored with the opening of the city's <a href="Soldiers%27%20and%20Sailors%27%20Monument%20%28Cleveland%29">Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument</a> on Public Square.
Growth and expansion.
After the war, the city witnessed rapid growth. Its prime geographic location as a transportation hub between the East Coast and the Midwest played an important role in its development as a commercial center. In 1874, the <a href="First%20Woman%27s%20National%20Temperance%20Convention">First Woman's National Temperance Convention</a> was held in Cleveland, and adopted the formation of the <a href="Woman%27s%20Christian%20Temperance%20Union">Woman's Christian Temperance Union</a>. Cleveland served as a destination for iron ore shipped from <a href="Minnesota">Minnesota</a>, along with coal transported by rail. In 1870, <a href="John%20D.%20Rockefeller">John D. Rockefeller</a> founded <a href="Standard%20Oil">Standard Oil</a> in Cleveland. In 1885, he moved its headquarters to <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>, which had become a center of finance and business.
By the early 20th century, Cleveland had emerged as a major American manufacturing center. Its businesses included automotive companies such as <a href="Peerless">Peerless</a>, People's, <a href="Jordan%20Motor%20Car%20Company">Jordan</a>, <a href="Chandler%20Motor%20Car">Chandler</a>, and <a href="Winton%20Motor%20Carriage%20Company">Winton</a>, maker of the first car driven across the U.S. Other manufacturers in Cleveland produced <a href="steam%20car">steam-powered</a> cars, which included those by <a href="White%20Motor%20Company">White</a> and <a href="Gaeth">Gaeth</a>, and <a href="electric%20car">electric car</a>s produced by <a href="Baker%20Motor%20Vehicle">Baker</a>. The city's industrial growth was accompanied by significant <a href="Strike%20action">strikes</a> and labor unrest, as workers demanded better working conditions. In 1881–86, 70-80% of strikes were successful in improving labor conditions in Cleveland.
Known as the "Sixth City" due to its position as the sixth largest U.S. city at the time, Cleveland counted major <a href="Progressive%20Era">Progressive Era</a> politicians among its leaders, most prominently the <a href="Populism">populist</a> Mayor <a href="Tom%20L.%20Johnson">Tom L. Johnson</a>, who was responsible for the development of the <a href="The%20Mall%20%28Cleveland%29">Cleveland Mall Plan</a>. The era of the <a href="City%20Beautiful%20movement">City Beautiful movement</a> in Cleveland architecture, this period also saw wealthy patrons support the establishment of the city's major cultural institutions. The most prominent among them were the <a href="Cleveland%20Museum%20of%20Art">Cleveland Museum of Art</a>, which opened in 1916, and the <a href="Cleveland%20Orchestra">Cleveland Orchestra</a>, established in 1918.
Cleveland's economic growth and industrial jobs attracted large waves of <a href="Immigration%20to%20the%20United%20States">immigrants</a> from <a href="Southern%20Europe">Southern</a> and <a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern Europe</a> as well as <a href="History%20of%20Ireland%20%281801%E2%80%931923%29">Ireland</a>. African American migrants from the rural <a href="Southern%20United%20States">South</a> also arrived in Cleveland (among other Northeastern and Midwestern cities) as part of the <a href="Great%20Migration%20%28African%20American%29">Great Migration</a> for jobs, constitutional rights, and relief from <a href="Jim%20Crow%20laws">racial discrimination</a>. Between 1910 and 1930, the African American population of Cleveland grew by more than 400%. By 1920, the year in which the <a href="Cleveland%20Guardians">Cleveland Indians</a> won their <a href="1920%20World%20Series">first World Series championship</a>, Cleveland had grown into a densely-populated metropolis of 796,841 with a foreign-born population of 30%, making it the fifth largest city in the nation. At this time, Cleveland saw the rise of radical labor movements in response to the conditions of the largely immigrant and migrant workers. In 1919, the city attracted national attention amid the <a href="First%20Red%20Scare">First Red Scare</a> for the <a href="May%20Day%20riots%20of%201919">Cleveland May Day Riots</a>, in which <a href="socialism">socialist</a> demonstrators clashed with anti-socialists.
Despite the immigration restrictions of <a href="Emergency%20Quota%20Act">1921</a> and <a href="Immigration%20Act%20of%201924">1924</a>, the city's population continued to grow throughout the 1920s. <a href="Prohibition%20in%20the%20United%20States">Prohibition</a> first took effect in Ohio in May 1919 (although it was not well-enforced in Cleveland), became law with the <a href="Volstead%20Act">Volstead Act</a> in 1920, and was eventually <a href="Twenty-first%20Amendment%20to%20the%20United%20States%20Constitution">repealed</a> nationally by <a href="United%20States%20Congress">Congress</a> in 1933. The ban on alcohol led to the rise of <a href="Speakeasy">speakeasies</a> throughout the city and organized crime gangs, such as the <a href="Mayfield%20Road%20Mob">Mayfield Road Mob</a>, who smuggled bootleg liquor across <a href="Lake%20Erie">Lake Erie</a> from Canada into Cleveland. The <a href="Roaring%20Twenties">Roaring Twenties</a> also saw the establishment of Cleveland's <a href="Playhouse%20Square">Playhouse Square</a> and the rise of the risqué <a href="Downtown%20Cleveland%23Short%20Vincent">Short Vincent</a> entertainment district. The Bal-Masque balls of the <a href="avant-garde">avant-garde</a> <a href="Kokoon%20Arts%20Club">Kokoon Arts Club</a> scandalized the city. <a href="Jazz">Jazz</a> came to prominence in Cleveland during this period.
In 1929, the city hosted the first of many <a href="National%20Air%20Races">National Air Races</a>, and <a href="Amelia%20Earhart">Amelia Earhart</a> flew to the city from <a href="Santa%20Monica%2C%20California">Santa Monica, California</a> in the <a href="Women%27s%20Air%20Derby">Women's Air Derby</a> (nicknamed the "Powder Puff Derby" by <a href="Will%20Rogers">Will Rogers</a>). The <a href="Van%20Sweringen%20brothers">Van Sweringen brothers</a> commenced construction of the <a href="Terminal%20Tower">Terminal Tower</a> <a href="skyscraper">skyscraper</a> in 1926 and, by the time it was dedicated in 1930, Cleveland had a population of over 900,000. The era of the <a href="flapper">flapper</a> also marked the beginning of the golden age in Downtown Cleveland retail, centered on major department stores <a href="Higbee%27s">Higbee's</a>, Bailey's, the <a href="May%20Company%20Ohio">May Company</a>, <a href="William%20Taylor%20%26amp%3B%20Son">Taylor's</a>, <a href="Halle%20Brothers%20Co.">Halle's</a>, and <a href="Sterling-Lindner%20Co.">Sterling Lindner Davis</a>, which collectively represented one of the largest and most <a href="fashion">fashion</a>able shopping districts in the country, often compared to New York's <a href="Fifth%20Avenue">Fifth Avenue</a>.
Cleveland was hit hard by the <a href="Wall%20Street%20Crash%20of%201929">Wall Street Crash of 1929</a> and the subsequent <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a>. A center of <a href="Labor%20unions%20in%20the%20United%20States">union activity</a>, the city saw significant labor struggles in this period, including strikes by workers against <a href="Fisher%20Body">Fisher Body</a> in 1936 and against <a href="Republic%20Steel">Republic Steel</a> in 1937. The city was also aided by major federal works projects sponsored by President <a href="Franklin%20D.%20Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a>'s <a href="New%20Deal">New Deal</a>. In commemoration of the centennial of Cleveland's incorporation as a city, the <a href="Great%20Lakes%20Exposition">Great Lakes Exposition</a> debuted in June 1936 at the city's <a href="North%20Coast%20Harbor">North Coast Harbor</a>, along the Lake Erie shore north of downtown. Conceived by Cleveland's business leaders as a way to revitalize the city during the Depression, it drew four million visitors in its first season, and seven million by the end of its second and final season in September 1937.
On December 7, 1941, <a href="Empire%20of%20Japan">Imperial Japan</a> <a href="Attack%20on%20Pearl%20Harbor">attacked Pearl Harbor</a> and <a href="Japanese%20declaration%20of%20war%20on%20the%20United%20States%20and%20the%20British%20Empire">declared war</a> on the United States. One of the victims of the attack was a Cleveland native, Rear Admiral <a href="Isaac%20C.%20Kidd">Isaac C. Kidd</a>. The attack signaled America's entry into <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. A major hub of the "<a href="Arsenal%20of%20Democracy">Arsenal of Democracy</a>", Cleveland under Mayor <a href="Frank%20Lausche">Frank Lausche</a> contributed massively to the <a href="United%20States%20home%20front%20during%20World%20War%20II">U.S. war effort</a> as the fifth largest manufacturing center in the nation. During his tenure, Lausche also oversaw the establishment of the Cleveland Transit System, the predecessor to the <a href="Greater%20Cleveland%20Regional%20Transit%20Authority">Greater Cleveland Regional Transit Authority</a>.
Late 20th and early 21st centuries.
After the war, Cleveland initially experienced an economic boom, and businesses declared the city to be the "best location in the nation". In 1949, the city was named an <a href="All-America%20City%20Award">All-America City</a> for the first time and, in 1950, its population reached 914,808. In sports, the Indians won the <a href="1948%20World%20Series">1948 World Series</a>, the hockey team, the <a href="Cleveland%20Barons%20%281937%E2%80%931973%29">Barons</a>, became champions of the American Hockey League, and the <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Browns</a> dominated professional <a href="National%20Football%20League">football</a> in the 1950s. As a result, along with track and boxing champions produced, Cleveland was declared the "City of Champions" in sports at this time. The 1950s also saw the rising popularity of a new music genre that local <a href="WKNR">WJW (AM)</a> disc jockey <a href="Alan%20Freed">Alan Freed</a> dubbed "<a href="rock%20and%20roll">rock and roll</a>".
However, by the 1960s, Cleveland's economy began to slow down, and residents increasingly sought new housing in the suburbs, reflecting the national trends of suburban growth following federally subsidized highways. Industrial restructuring, particularly in the railroad and steel industries, resulted in the loss of numerous jobs in Cleveland and the region, and the city suffered economically. The <a href="burning%20of%20the%20Cuyahoga%20River">burning of the Cuyahoga River</a> in June 1969 brought national attention to the issue of <a href="Pollution%23Urban%20pollution">industrial pollution</a> in Cleveland and served as a catalyst for the <a href="Environmental%20movement%20in%20the%20United%20States">American environmental movement</a>.
<a href="Housing%20discrimination%20in%20the%20United%20States">Housing discrimination</a> and <a href="redlining">redlining</a> against African Americans led to racial unrest in Cleveland and numerous other Northern U.S. cities. In Cleveland, the <a href="Hough%20riots">Hough riots</a> erupted from July 18 to 23, 1966, and the <a href="Glenville%20Shootout">Glenville Shootout</a> took place from July 23 to 25, 1968. In November 1967, Cleveland became the first major American city to elect an African American mayor, <a href="Carl%20Stokes">Carl B. Stokes</a>, who served from 1968 to 1971 and played an instrumental role in restoring the Cuyahoga River.
In December 1978, during the turbulent tenure of <a href="Dennis%20Kucinich">Dennis Kucinich</a> as mayor, Cleveland became the first major American city since the Great Depression to enter into a <a href="default%20%28finance%29">financial default</a> on federal loans. By the beginning of the 1980s, several factors, including changes in international <a href="free%20trade">free trade</a> policies, inflation, and the <a href="savings%20and%20loan%20crisis">savings and loan crisis</a>, contributed to <a href="Early%201980s%20recession">the recession</a> that severely affected cities like Cleveland. While unemployment during the period peaked in 1983, Cleveland's rate of 13.8% was higher than the national average due to the closure of several steel production centers.
The city began a gradual economic recovery under Mayor <a href="George%20Voinovich">George V. Voinovich</a> in the 1980s. The downtown area saw the construction of the <a href="Key%20Tower">Key Tower</a> and <a href="200%20Public%20Square">200 Public Square</a> skyscrapers, as well as the development of the <a href="Gateway%20Sports%20and%20Entertainment%20Complex">Gateway Sports and Entertainment Complex</a>—consisting of <a href="Progressive%20Field">Progressive Field</a> and <a href="Rocket%20Mortgage%20FieldHouse">Rocket Mortgage FieldHouse</a>—and the North Coast Harbor, including the <a href="Rock%20and%20Roll%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Rock and Roll Hall of Fame</a>, <a href="FirstEnergy%20Stadium">FirstEnergy Stadium</a>, and the <a href="Great%20Lakes%20Science%20Center">Great Lakes Science Center</a>. The city emerged from default in 1987.
By the turn of the 21st century, Cleveland succeeded in developing a more diversified economy and gained a national reputation as a center for healthcare and the arts. Additionally, it has become a national leader in environmental protection, with its successful cleanup of the Cuyahoga River. The city's downtown has experienced dramatic economic and population growth since 2010, but the overall population has continued to decline. Challenges remain for the city, with economic development of neighborhoods, improvement of <a href="Cleveland%20Metropolitan%20School%20District">city schools</a>, and continued encouragement of new immigration to Cleveland being top municipal priorities.
Geography.
According to the <a href="United%20States%20Census%20Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a>, the city has a total area of , of which is land and is water. The shore of Lake Erie is above <a href="above%20mean%20sea%20level">sea level</a>; however, the city lies on a series of irregular bluffs lying roughly parallel to the lake. In Cleveland these bluffs are cut principally by the <a href="Cuyahoga%20River">Cuyahoga River</a>, Big Creek, and <a href="Euclid%20Creek">Euclid Creek</a>.
The land rises quickly from the lake shore elevation of 569 feet. Public Square, less than inland, sits at an elevation of , and Hopkins Airport, inland from the lake, is at an elevation of .
Cleveland borders several <a href="Inner%20suburb">inner-ring</a> and <a href="streetcar%20suburbs">streetcar</a> <a href="suburb">suburb</a>s. To the west, it borders <a href="Lakewood%2C%20Ohio">Lakewood</a>, <a href="Rocky%20River%2C%20Ohio">Rocky River</a>, and <a href="Fairview%20Park%2C%20Ohio">Fairview Park</a>, and to the east, it borders <a href="Shaker%20Heights%2C%20Ohio">Shaker Heights</a>, <a href="Cleveland%20Heights%2C%20Ohio">Cleveland Heights</a>, <a href="South%20Euclid%2C%20Ohio">South Euclid</a>, and <a href="East%20Cleveland%2C%20Ohio">East Cleveland</a>. To the southwest, it borders <a href="Linndale%2C%20Ohio">Linndale</a>, <a href="Brooklyn%2C%20Ohio">Brooklyn</a>, <a href="Parma%2C%20Ohio">Parma</a>, and <a href="Brook%20Park%2C%20Ohio">Brook Park</a>. To the south, the city also borders <a href="Newburgh%20Heights%2C%20Ohio">Newburgh Heights</a>, <a href="Cuyahoga%20Heights%2C%20Ohio">Cuyahoga Heights</a>, and <a href="Brooklyn%20Heights%2C%20Ohio">Brooklyn Heights</a> and to the southeast, it borders <a href="Warrensville%20Heights%2C%20Ohio">Warrensville Heights</a>, <a href="Maple%20Heights%2C%20Ohio">Maple Heights</a>, and <a href="Garfield%20Heights%2C%20Ohio">Garfield Heights</a>. To the northeast, along the shore of Lake Erie, Cleveland borders <a href="Bratenahl%2C%20Ohio">Bratenahl</a> and <a href="Euclid%2C%20Ohio">Euclid</a>.
Architecture.
Cleveland's downtown architecture is diverse. Many of the city's government and civic buildings, including <a href="Cleveland%20City%20Hall">City Hall</a>, the <a href="Cuyahoga%20County%20Courthouse">Cuyahoga County Courthouse</a>, the <a href="Cleveland%20Public%20Library">Cleveland Public Library</a>, and <a href="Public%20Auditorium">Public Auditorium</a>, are clustered around the open Cleveland Mall and share a common <a href="neoclassical%20architecture">neoclassical architecture</a>. They were built in the early 20th century as the result of the 1903 Group Plan. They constitute one of the most complete examples of City Beautiful design in the United States.
Completed in 1927 and dedicated in 1930 as part of the <a href="Tower%20City%20Center">Cleveland Union Terminal</a> complex, the Terminal Tower was the tallest building in North America outside New York City until 1964 and the tallest in the city until 1991. It is a prototypical <a href="Beaux-Arts%20architecture">Beaux-Arts</a> skyscraper. The two newer skyscrapers on Public Square, Key Tower (currently the tallest building in Ohio) and the 200 Public Square, combine elements of <a href="Art%20Deco">Art Deco</a> architecture with <a href="postmodern%20architecture">postmodern</a> designs. Cleveland's architectural treasures also include the <a href="Cleveland%20Trust%20Company%20Building">Cleveland Trust Company Building</a>, completed in 1907 and renovated in 2015 as a downtown <a href="Heinen%27s%20Fine%20Foods">Heinen's</a> <a href="supermarket">supermarket</a>, and the <a href="Cleveland%20Arcade">Cleveland Arcade</a> (sometimes called the Old Arcade), a five-story <a href="arcade%20%28architecture%29">arcade</a> built in 1890 and renovated in 2001 as a <a href="Hyatt">Hyatt</a> Regency Hotel.
Running east from Public Square through University Circle is <a href="Euclid%20Avenue%20%28Cleveland%29">Euclid Avenue</a>, which was known for its prestige and elegance as a residential street. In the late 1880s, writer <a href="Bayard%20Taylor">Bayard Taylor</a> described it as "the most beautiful street in the world". Known as "Millionaires' Row", Euclid Avenue was world-renowned as the home of such major figures as John D. Rockefeller, <a href="Mark%20Hanna">Mark Hanna</a>, and <a href="John%20Hay">John Hay</a>.
Cleveland's landmark <a href="ecclesiastical%20architecture">ecclesiastical architecture</a> includes the historic <a href="Old%20Stone%20Church%20%28Cleveland%29">Old Stone Church</a> in downtown Cleveland and the <a href="onion%20dome">onion dome</a>d <a href="St.%20Theodosius%20Russian%20Orthodox%20Cathedral">St. Theodosius Russian Orthodox Cathedral</a> in <a href="Tremont%2C%20Cleveland">Tremont</a>, along with myriad ethnically inspired Roman Catholic churches.
Parks and nature.
Known locally as the "Emerald Necklace", the <a href="Frederick%20Law%20Olmsted">Olmsted</a>-inspired Cleveland Metroparks encircle Cleveland and Cuyahoga County. The city proper is home to the Metroparks' Brookside and Lakefront Reservations, as well as significant parts of the Rocky River, Washington, and Euclid Creek Reservations. The Lakefront Reservation, which provides public access to Lake Erie, consists of four parks: Edgewater Park, <a href="Whiskey%20Island%20%28Cleveland%29">Whiskey Island–Wendy Park</a>, East 55th Street Marina, and <a href="Gordon%20Park%2C%20Cleveland">Gordon Park</a>. Three more parks fall under the jurisdiction of the Euclid Creek Reservation: Euclid Beach, Villa Angela, and Wildwood Marina. Bike and hiking trails in the <a href="Brecksville%20Reservation">Brecksville</a> and Bedford Reservations, along with Garfield Park further north, provide access to trails in the <a href="Cuyahoga%20Valley%20National%20Park">Cuyahoga Valley National Park</a>. The extensive system of trails within Cuyahoga Valley National Park extends south into <a href="Summit%20County%2C%20Ohio">Summit County</a>, offering access to <a href="Summit%20Metro%20Parks">Summit Metro Parks</a> as well. Also included in the system is the renowned <a href="Cleveland%20Metroparks%20Zoo">Cleveland Metroparks Zoo</a>, established in 1882. Located in Big Creek Valley, the zoo has one of the largest collections of <a href="primate">primate</a>s in North America.
The Cleveland Metroparks provides ample opportunity for outdoor recreational activities. Hiking and biking trails, including single-track mountain bike trails, wind extensively throughout the parks. Rock climbing is available at Whipp's Ledges at the Hinckley Reservation. During the summer months, kayakers, paddle boarders, and rowing and sailing crews can be seen on the Cuyahoga River and Lake Erie. In the winter months, downhill skiing, snowboarding, and tubing are available not far from downtown at the <a href="Boston%20Mills/Brandywine%20Ski%20Resort">Boston Mills/Brandywine</a> and <a href="Alpine%20Valley%20Ski%20Area">Alpine Valley</a> ski resorts.
In addition to the Metroparks, the Cleveland Public Parks District oversees the city's neighborhood parks, the largest of which is the historic <a href="Rockefeller%20Park">Rockefeller Park</a>. The latter is notable for its late 19th century landmark bridges, the Rockefeller Park Greenhouse, and the <a href="Cleveland%20Cultural%20Gardens">Cleveland Cultural Gardens</a>, which celebrate the city's ethnic diversity. Just outside of Rockefeller Park, the <a href="Cleveland%20Botanical%20Garden">Cleveland Botanical Garden</a> in University Circle, established in 1930, is the oldest civic garden center in the nation. In addition, the <a href="Greater%20Cleveland%20Aquarium">Greater Cleveland Aquarium</a>, located in the historic FirstEnergy Powerhouse in the <a href="The%20Flats">Flats</a>, is the only independent, free-standing aquarium in the state of Ohio.
Neighborhoods.
The Cleveland City Planning Commission has officially designated 34 neighborhoods in Cleveland. Centered on Public Square, <a href="Downtown%20Cleveland">Downtown Cleveland</a> is the city's <a href="central%20business%20district">central business district</a>, encompassing a wide range of subdistricts, such as the <a href="Nine-Twelve%20District">Nine-Twelve District</a>, the <a href="Campus%20District">Campus District</a>, the <a href="Civic%20Center%20%28Cleveland%29">Civic Center</a>, and <a href="Playhouse%20Square">Playhouse Square</a>. It also historically included the lively Short Vincent entertainment district, which emerged in the 1920s, reached its height in the 1940s and 1950s, and disappeared with the expansion of National City Bank in the late 1970s. Mixed-use areas, such as the <a href="Warehouse%20District%2C%20Cleveland">Warehouse District</a> and the <a href="Downtown%20Cleveland%23Superior%20Arts%20District">Superior Arts District</a>, are occupied by industrial and office buildings as well as restaurants, cafes, and bars. The number of downtown <a href="condominium">condominium</a>s, <a href="loft%20apartment">lofts</a>, and apartments has been on the increase since 2000 and especially 2010, reflecting the neighborhood's dramatic population growth. Recent downtown developments also include the <a href="HealthLine">Euclid Corridor Project</a> and the revival of <a href="East%204th%20Street%20District%20%28Cleveland%29">East 4th Street</a>.
Clevelanders geographically define themselves in terms of whether they live on the east or west side of the Cuyahoga River. The East Side includes the neighborhoods of <a href="Buckeye%E2%80%93Shaker">Buckeye–Shaker</a>, <a href="Buckeye%E2%80%93Woodhill">Buckeye–Woodhill</a>, <a href="Central%2C%20Cleveland">Central</a>, <a href="Collinwood">Collinwood</a> (including <a href="Nottingham%2C%20Ohio">Nottingham</a>), <a href="Euclid%E2%80%93Green">Euclid–Green</a>, <a href="Fairfax%2C%20Cleveland">Fairfax</a>, <a href="Glenville%2C%20Cleveland">Glenville</a>, <a href="Goodrich%E2%80%93Kirtland%20Park">Goodrich–Kirtland Park</a> (including <a href="Asiatown%2C%20Cleveland">Asiatown</a>), <a href="Hough%2C%20Cleveland">Hough</a>, <a href="Kinsman%2C%20Cleveland">Kinsman</a>, <a href="Lee%E2%80%93Miles">Lee–Miles</a> (including Lee–Harvard and Lee–Seville), <a href="Mount%20Pleasant%2C%20Cleveland">Mount Pleasant</a>, <a href="St.%20Clair%E2%80%93Superior">St. Clair–Superior</a>, <a href="Union%E2%80%93Miles%20Park">Union–Miles Park</a>, and <a href="University%20Circle">University Circle</a> (including <a href="Little%20Italy%2C%20Cleveland">Little Italy</a>). The West Side includes the neighborhoods of <a href="Brooklyn%20Centre">Brooklyn Centre</a>, <a href="Clark%E2%80%93Fulton">Clark–Fulton</a>, <a href="Cudell%2C%20Cleveland">Cudell</a>, <a href="Detroit%E2%80%93Shoreway">Detroit–Shoreway</a>, <a href="Edgewater%2C%20Cleveland">Edgewater</a>, <a href="Ohio%20City%2C%20Cleveland">Ohio City</a>, <a href="Old%20Brooklyn">Old Brooklyn</a>, <a href="Stockyards%2C%20Cleveland">Stockyards</a>, <a href="Tremont%2C%20Cleveland">Tremont</a> (including <a href="Tremont%2C%20Cleveland%23Duck%20Island">Duck Island</a>), <a href="West%20Boulevard">West Boulevard</a>, and the four neighborhoods colloquially known as <a href="West%20Park%2C%20Cleveland">West Park</a>: <a href="Kamm%27s%20Corners">Kamm's Corners</a>, <a href="Jefferson%2C%20Cleveland">Jefferson</a>, <a href="Bellaire%E2%80%93Puritas%2C%20Cleveland">Bellaire–Puritas</a>, and <a href="Hopkins%2C%20Cleveland">Hopkins</a>. The <a href="Cuyahoga%20Valley%2C%20Cleveland">Cuyahoga Valley</a> neighborhood (including <a href="the%20Flats">the Flats</a>) is situated between the East and West Sides, while the <a href="Broadway%E2%80%93Slavic%20Village">Broadway–Slavic Village</a> neighborhood is sometimes referred to as the South Side.
Several neighborhoods have begun to attract the return of the middle class that left the city for the suburbs in the 1960s and 1970s. These neighborhoods are on both the West Side (Ohio City, Tremont, Detroit–Shoreway, and Edgewater) and the East Side (Collinwood, Hough, Fairfax, and Little Italy). Much of the growth has been spurred on by attracting <a href="creative%20class">creative class</a> members, which in turn is spurring new residential development. A live-work <a href="zoning">zoning</a> overlay for the city's near East Side has facilitated the transformation of old industrial buildings into loft spaces for artists.
Climate.
Typical of the Great Lakes region, Cleveland exhibits a <a href="continental%20climate">continental climate</a> with four distinct seasons, which lies in the <a href="humid%20continental">humid continental</a> (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen</a> "Dfa") zone. Summers are hot and humid while winters are cold and snowy. The Lake Erie shoreline is very close to due east–west from the mouth of the Cuyahoga west to <a href="Sandusky%2C%20Ohio">Sandusky</a>, but at the mouth of the Cuyahoga it turns sharply northeast. This feature is the principal contributor to the <a href="lake-effect%20snow">lake-effect snow</a> that is typical in Cleveland (especially on the city's East Side) from mid-November until the surface of Lake Erie freezes, usually in late January or early February. The lake effect also causes a relative differential in geographical snowfall totals across the city: while Hopkins Airport, on the city's far West Side, has only reached of snowfall in a season three times since record-keeping for snow began in 1893, seasonal totals approaching or exceeding are not uncommon as the city ascends into the Heights on the east, where the region known as the '<a href="Snowbelt">Snow Belt</a>' begins. Extending from the city's East Side and its suburbs, the Snow Belt reaches up the Lake Erie shore as far as <a href="Buffalo%2C%20New%20York">Buffalo</a>.
The all-time record high in Cleveland of was established on June 25, 1988, and the all-time record low of was set on January 19, 1994. On average, July is the warmest month with a mean temperature of , and January, with a mean temperature of , is the coldest. The least precipitation occurs on the western side and directly along the lake, and the most occurs in the eastern suburbs.
