Demographics.
At the 2020 <a href="census">census</a>, there were 372,624 people and 170,549 households in the city. The population density was .
The median income for a household in the city was $30,907. The per capita income for the city was $21,223. 32.7% of the population living below the poverty line. Of the city's population over the age of 25, 17.5% held a bachelor's degree or higher, and 80.8% had a high school diploma or equivalent.
According to the 2010 census, 29.7% of Cleveland households had children under the age of 18 living with them, 22.4% were married couples living together, 25.3% had a female householder with no husband present, 6.0% had a male householder with no wife present, and 46.4% were non-families. 39.5% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.29 and the average family size was 3.11.
In 2010, the median age in the city was 35.7 years. 24.6% of residents were under the age of 18; 11% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 26.1% were from 25 to 44; 26.3% were from 45 to 64; and 12% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 48.0% male and 52.0% female.
Ethnicity.
According to the 2020 census, the racial composition of the city was 40.0% <a href="White%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">white</a>, 48.8% African American, 0.5% <a href="Native%20Americans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Native American</a>, 2.6% <a href="Asian%20Americans">Asian</a>, and 4.4% from <a href="Multiracial%20Americans">two or more races</a>. <a href="Hispanic%20and%20Latino%20Americans">Hispanics or Latinos</a> of any race were 11.9% of the population.
In the 19th and early 20th centuries, Cleveland saw a massive influx of immigrants from Ireland, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Italy">Italy</a>, and the <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austro-Hungarian</a>, <a href="German%20Empire">German</a>, <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian</a>, and <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman</a> empires, most of whom were attracted by manufacturing jobs. As a result, Cleveland and Cuyahoga County today have substantial communities of <a href="Irish%20Americans">Irish</a> (especially in Kamm's Corners and other areas of West Park), <a href="Italian%20Americans">Italians</a> (especially in Little Italy and around <a href="U.S.%20Route%20322">Mayfield Road</a>), <a href="German%20Americans">Germans</a>, and several <a href="Central%20Europe">Central</a>-Eastern European ethnicities, including <a href="Czech%20American">Czechs</a>, <a href="Hungarian%20Americans">Hungarians</a>, <a href="Lithuanian%20American">Lithuanians</a>, <a href="Polish%20Americans">Poles</a>, <a href="Romanian%20American">Romanians</a>, <a href="Russian%20Americans">Russians</a>, <a href="Rusyn%20Americans">Rusyns</a>, <a href="Slovak%20American">Slovaks</a>, <a href="Ukrainian%20American">Ukrainians</a>, and ex-<a href="Yugoslavia">Yugoslav</a> groups, such as <a href="Slovene%20Americans">Slovenes</a>, <a href="Croatian%20American">Croats</a> and <a href="Serbian%20American">Serbs</a>. The presence of <a href="Hungarian%20Ohioans%23Hungarians%20in%20Cleveland">Hungarians within Cleveland proper</a> was, at one time, so great that the city boasted the highest concentration of Hungarians in the world outside of <a href="Budapest">Budapest</a>. Cleveland has a long-established <a href="Jews%20and%20Judaism%20in%20Greater%20Cleveland">Jewish community</a>, historically centered on the East Side neighborhoods of Glenville and Kinsman, but now mostly concentrated in East Side suburbs such as Cleveland Heights and <a href="Beachwood%2C%20Ohio">Beachwood</a>, home to the <a href="Maltz%20Museum%20of%20Jewish%20Heritage">Maltz Museum of Jewish Heritage</a>.
The availability of jobs also attracted African Americans from the South. Between 1920 and 1970, the black population of Cleveland, largely concentrated on the city's East Side, increased significantly as a result of the First and <a href="Second%20Great%20Migration%20%28African%20American%29">Second Great Migrations</a>. Cleveland's Latino community consists primarily of <a href="Puerto%20Ricans%20in%20the%20United%20States">Puerto Ricans</a>, who make up over 80% of the city's Hispanic/Latino population, as well as smaller numbers of immigrants from <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>, <a href="Cuba">Cuba</a>, the <a href="Dominican%20Republic">Dominican Republic</a>, <a href="South%20America">South</a> and <a href="Central%20America">Central America</a>, and <a href="Spain">Spain</a>. The city's Asian community, centered on historical Asiatown, consists of <a href="Chinese%20Americans">Chinese</a>, <a href="Korean%20Americans">Koreans</a>, <a href="Vietnamese%20Americans">Vietnamese</a>, and other groups. Additionally, the city and the county have significant communities of <a href="Albanian%20Americans">Albanians</a>, <a href="Arab%20American">Arabs</a> (especially <a href="Lebanese%20Americans">Lebanese</a>, <a href="Syrian%20Americans">Syrians</a>, and <a href="Palestinian%20Americans">Palestinians</a>), <a href="Armenian%20Americans">Armenians</a>, <a href="French%20American">French</a>, <a href="Greek%20American">Greeks</a>, <a href="Iranian%20Americans">Iranians</a>, <a href="Scottish%20Americans">Scots</a>, <a href="Turkish%20Americans">Turks</a>, and <a href="West%20Indian%20American">West Indians</a>. A 2020 analysis found Cleveland to be the most ethnically and racially diverse city in Ohio.
Many ethnic festivals are held in Cleveland throughout the year, such as the annual <a href="Cleveland%20Feast%20of%20the%20Assumption%20Festival">Feast of the Assumption</a> in Little Italy, Russian <a href="Maslenitsa">Maslenitsa</a> in Rockefeller Park, the Cleveland Puerto Rican Parade and Festival in Clark–Fulton, the Cleveland Asian Festival in Asiatown, the Greek Festival in Tremont, and the Romanian Festival in West Park. Vendors at the <a href="West%20Side%20Market">West Side Market</a> in Ohio City offer many ethnic foods for sale. Cleveland also hosts annual Polish <a href="%C5%9Amigus-dyngus">Dyngus Day</a> and Slovene <a href="Kurentovanje">Kurentovanje</a> celebrations. The city's annual <a href="Saint%20Patrick%27s%20Day">Saint Patrick's Day</a> parade brings hundreds of thousands to the streets of Downtown. The <a href="Cleveland%20Thyagaraja%20Festival">Cleveland Thyagaraja Festival</a> held annually each spring at <a href="Cleveland%20State%20University">Cleveland State University</a> is the largest <a href="Indian%20people">Indian</a> classical music and dance festival in the world outside of <a href="India">India</a>. Since 1946, the city has annually marked One World Day in the Cleveland Cultural Gardens in Rockefeller Park, celebrating all of its ethnic communities.
Religion.
The influx of immigrants in the 19th and early 20th centuries drastically transformed Cleveland's religious landscape. From a homogeneous settlement of New England <a href="Protestantism">Protestants</a>, it evolved into a city with a diverse religious composition. The predominant faith among Clevelanders today is <a href="Christianity">Christianity</a> (<a href="Catholic%20Church">Catholic</a>, Protestant, and <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox%20Church">Eastern</a> and <a href="Oriental%20Orthodox%20Churches">Oriental Orthodox</a>), with <a href="Judaism">Jewish</a>, <a href="Islam">Muslim</a>, <a href="Hinduism">Hindu</a>, and <a href="Buddhism">Buddhist</a> minorities.
Language.
, 85.3% of Cleveland residents age 5 and older spoke English at home as a primary language. 14.7% spoke a foreign language, including <a href="Spanish%20language%20in%20the%20United%20States">Spanish</a>, <a href="Arabic%20language%20in%20the%20United%20States">Arabic</a>, <a href="Chinese%20language%20in%20the%20United%20States">Chinese</a>, <a href="Albanian%20language">Albanian</a>, and various <a href="Slavic%20languages">Slavic languages</a> (<a href="Russian%20language%20in%20the%20United%20States">Russian</a>, <a href="Polish%20language">Polish</a>, <a href="Serbo-Croatian%20language">Serbo-Croatian</a>, and <a href="Slovene%20language">Slovene</a>).
Immigration.
In 1920, Cleveland proper boasted a foreign-born population of 30% and, in 1870, that percentage was 42%. Although the foreign-born population of Cleveland today is not as big as it once was, the sense of identity remains strong among the city's various ethnic communities, as reflected in the Cleveland Cultural Gardens. Within Cleveland, the neighborhoods with the highest foreign-born populations are Asiatown/Goodrich–Kirtland Park (32.7%), Clark–Fulton (26.7%), West Boulevard (18.5%), Brooklyn Centre (17.3%), Downtown (17.2%), University Circle (15.9%, with 20% in Little Italy), and Jefferson (14.3%). Recent waves of immigration have brought new groups to Cleveland, including <a href="Ethiopian%20Americans">Ethiopians</a> and <a href="South%20Asian%20Americans">South Asians</a>, as well as immigrants from <a href="Russia">Russia</a> and the <a href="Post-Soviet%20states">former USSR</a>, <a href="Southeast%20Europe">Southeast Europe</a> (especially <a href="Albania">Albania</a>), the <a href="Middle%20East">Middle East</a>, <a href="East%20Asia">East Asia</a>, and <a href="Latin%20America">Latin America</a>. In the 2010s, the immigrant population of Cleveland and Cuyahoga County began to see significant growth, becoming one of the fastest growing centers for immigration in the Great Lakes region. A 2019 study found Cleveland to be the city with the shortest average processing time in the nation for immigrants to become <a href="Citizenship%20of%20the%20United%20States">U.S. citizens</a>. The city's annual One World Day in Rockefeller Park includes a naturalization ceremony of new immigrants.
Economy.
Cleveland's location on the Cuyahoga River and Lake Erie has been key to its growth. The Ohio and Erie Canal coupled with rail links helped the city become an important business center. Steel and many other manufactured goods emerged as leading industries. The city has since diversified its economy in addition to its manufacturing sector.
Established in 1914, the <a href="Federal%20Reserve%20Bank%20of%20Cleveland">Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland</a> is one of 12 U.S. <a href="Federal%20Reserve">Federal Reserve</a> <a href="Federal%20Reserve%20Bank">Banks</a>. Its downtown building, located on East 6th Street and Superior Avenue, was completed in 1923 by the Cleveland architectural firm <a href="Walker%20and%20Weeks">Walker and Weeks</a>. The headquarters of the Federal Reserve System's Fourth District, the bank employs 1,000 people and maintains branch offices in <a href="Cincinnati">Cincinnati</a> and <a href="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a>. The <a href="chief%20executive%20officer">chief executive officer</a> and <a href="president%20%28corporate%20title%29">president</a> is <a href="Loretta%20Mester">Loretta Mester</a>.
The city is also home to the corporate headquarters of many large companies such as <a href="Aleris">Aleris</a>, <a href="American%20Greetings">American Greetings</a>, <a href="Applied%20Industrial%20Technologies">Applied Industrial Technologies</a>, <a href="Mettler%20Toledo">Mettler Toledo</a>, <a href="Cliffs%20Natural%20Resources">Cleveland-Cliffs, Inc.</a>, <a href="Eaton%20Corporation">Eaton</a>, <a href="Forest%20City%20Enterprises">Forest City Enterprises</a>, Heinen's Fine Foods, <a href="Hyster-Yale%20Materials%20Handling">Hyster-Yale Materials Handling</a>, <a href="Key%20Bank">KeyCorp</a>, <a href="Lincoln%20Electric">Lincoln Electric</a>, <a href="Medical%20Mutual%20of%20Ohio">Medical Mutual of Ohio</a>, <a href="Moen%20Incorporated">Moen Incorporated</a>, <a href="NACCO%20Industries">NACCO Industries</a>, <a href="Nordson">Nordson</a>, <a href="OM%20Group">OM Group</a>, <a href="Parker-Hannifin">Parker-Hannifin</a>, <a href="PolyOne">PolyOne</a>, <a href="Progressive%20Corporation">Progressive</a>, <a href="RPM%20International">RPM International</a>, <a href="Sherwin-Williams%20Company">Sherwin-Williams Company</a>, <a href="Steris">Steris</a>, <a href="Swagelok">Swagelok</a>, <a href="Things%20Remembered">Things Remembered</a>, <a href="Third%20Federal%20S%26amp%3BL">Third Federal S&L</a>, <a href="TransDigm%20Group">TransDigm Group</a>, <a href="Travel%20Centers%20of%20America">Travel Centers of America</a> and <a href="Vitamix">Vitamix</a>. <a href="NASA">NASA</a> maintains a facility in Cleveland, the <a href="Glenn%20Research%20Center">Glenn Research Center</a>. <a href="Jones%20Day">Jones Day</a>, one of the largest law firms in the U.S., was founded in Cleveland.
The <a href="Cleveland%20Clinic">Cleveland Clinic</a> is the largest private employer in the city of Cleveland and the state of Ohio, with a workforce of over 50,000 . It carries the distinction as being among America's best hospitals with top ratings published in "<a href="U.S.%20News%20%26amp%3B%20World%20Report">U.S. News & World Report</a>". Cleveland's healthcare sector also includes <a href="University%20Hospitals%20Cleveland%20Medical%20Center">University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center</a>, <a href="MetroHealth">MetroHealth</a> medical center, and the insurance company Medical Mutual of Ohio. Cleveland is also noted in the fields of <a href="biotechnology">biotechnology</a> and <a href="fuel%20cell">fuel cell</a> research, led by <a href="Case%20Western%20Reserve%20University">Case Western Reserve University</a>, the Cleveland Clinic, and University Hospitals of Cleveland. The city is among the top recipients of investment for biotech start-ups and research.
Technology is another growing sector in Cleveland. In 2005, the city appointed a "tech czar" to recruit technology companies to the downtown office market, offering connections to the high-speed fiber networks that run underneath downtown streets in several "high-tech offices" focused on Euclid Avenue. Cleveland State University hired a technology transfer officer to cultivate technology transfers from CSU research to marketable ideas and companies in the Cleveland area. Local observers have noted that the city is transitioning from a manufacturing-based economy to a health-tech-based economy.
Education.
Primary and secondary education.
The Cleveland Metropolitan School District is the second-largest <a href="K%E2%80%9312%20education">K–12</a> district in the state of Ohio. It is the only district in Ohio under the direct control of the mayor, who appoints a <a href="board%20of%20education">school board</a>. Approximately of Cleveland, adjacent the <a href="Shaker%20Square">Shaker Square</a> neighborhood, is part of the <a href="Shaker%20Heights%20City%20School%20District">Shaker Heights City School District</a>. The area, which has been a part of the Shaker school district since the 1920s, permits these Cleveland residents to pay the same school taxes as the Shaker residents, as well as vote in the Shaker school board elections.
Private and parochial schools within Cleveland proper include <a href="Benedictine%20High%20School%20%28Cleveland%2C%20Ohio%29">Benedictine High School</a>, Birchwood School, <a href="Cleveland%20Central%20Catholic%20High%20School">Cleveland Central Catholic High School</a>, <a href="Eleanor%20Gerson%20School">Eleanor Gerson School</a>, <a href="Montessori%20High%20School%20at%20University%20Circle">Montessori High School at University Circle</a>, <a href="Saint%20Ignatius%20High%20School%20%28Cleveland%29">St. Ignatius High School</a>, <a href="Saint%20Joseph%20Academy%20%28Cleveland%2C%20Ohio%29">St. Joseph Academy</a>, <a href="Villa%20Angela-St.%20Joseph%20High%20School">Villa Angela-St. Joseph High School</a>, Urban Community School, <a href="St.%20Martin%20de%20Porres%20High%20School%20%28Cleveland%29">St. Martin de Porres</a>, and The Bridge Avenue School.
Higher education.
Cleveland is home to a number of colleges and universities. Most prominent among them is <a href="Case%20Western%20Reserve%20University">Case Western Reserve University</a> (CWRU), a widely recognized research and teaching institution in University Circle. A private university with several prominent graduate programs, CWRU was ranked 40th in the nation in 2020 by "U.S. News & World Report". University Circle also contains the <a href="Cleveland%20Institute%20of%20Art">Cleveland Institute of Art</a> and the <a href="Cleveland%20Institute%20of%20Music">Cleveland Institute of Music</a>. <a href="Cleveland%20State%20University">Cleveland State University</a> (CSU), based in Downtown Cleveland, is the city's public four-year university. In addition to CSU, downtown hosts the metropolitan campus of <a href="Cuyahoga%20Community%20College">Cuyahoga Community College</a>, the county's two-year higher education institution. <a href="Ohio%20Technical%20College">Ohio Technical College</a> is also based in Cleveland. Cleveland's suburban universities and colleges include <a href="Baldwin%20Wallace%20University">Baldwin Wallace University</a> in <a href="Berea%2C%20Ohio">Berea</a>, <a href="John%20Carroll%20University">John Carroll University</a> in <a href="University%20Heights%2C%20Ohio">University Heights</a>, <a href="Ursuline%20College">Ursuline College</a> in <a href="Pepper%20Pike%2C%20Ohio">Pepper Pike</a>, and <a href="Notre%20Dame%20College">Notre Dame College</a> in South Euclid.
Public library system.
Established in 1869, the Cleveland Public Library is one of the <a href="List%20of%20the%20largest%20libraries%20in%20the%20United%20States">largest public libraries</a> in the nation with a collection of 10,559,651 materials in 2018. Its <a href="John%20Griswold%20White">John G. White</a> Special Collection includes the largest <a href="chess%20libraries">chess library</a> in the world as well as a significant collection of <a href="folklore">folklore</a> and rare books on the Middle East and <a href="Eurasia">Eurasia</a>. Under head librarian <a href="William%20Howard%20Brett">William Howard Brett</a>, the library adopted an "open shelf" philosophy, which allowed patrons open access to the library's bookstacks. Brett's successor, <a href="Linda%20Eastman">Linda Eastman</a>, became the first woman ever to lead a major library system in the world. She oversaw the construction of the library's main building on Superior Avenue, designed by Walker and Weeks and opened on May 6, 1925. <a href="David%20Lloyd%20George">David Lloyd George</a>, <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">British Prime Minister</a> from 1916 to 1922, laid the cornerstone for the building. The Louis Stokes Wing addition was completed in April 1997. Between 1904 and 1920, 15 libraries <a href="Carnegie%20library">built with funds from</a> <a href="Andrew%20Carnegie">Andrew Carnegie</a> were opened in the city. Known as the "People's University," the library presently maintains 27 branches. It serves as the headquarters for the <a href="CLEVNET">CLEVNET</a> <a href="library%20consortium">library consortium</a>, which includes over 40 public library systems in the Greater Cleveland Metropolitan Area and Northeast Ohio.
Culture.
Performing arts.
Cleveland is home to Playhouse Square, the second largest performing arts center in the United States behind New York City's <a href="Lincoln%20Center">Lincoln Center</a>. Playhouse Square includes the <a href="State%20Theater%20%28Cleveland%29">State</a>, <a href="Palace%20Theater%2C%20Cleveland">Palace</a>, <a href="Allen%20Theatre">Allen</a>, <a href="Hanna%20Theater">Hanna</a>, and <a href="Ohio%20Theater%20%28Cleveland%29">Ohio</a> theaters within what is known as the Cleveland Theater District. The center hosts <a href="musical%20theatre">Broadway musicals</a>, special concerts, speaking engagements, and other events throughout the year. Its resident performing arts companies include <a href="Cleveland%20Ballet%20%28founded%202014%29">Cleveland Ballet</a>, the <a href="Cleveland%20International%20Film%20Festival">Cleveland International Film Festival</a>, the <a href="Cleveland%20Play%20House">Cleveland Play House</a>, Cleveland State University Department of Theatre and Dance, DANCECleveland, the <a href="Great%20Lakes%20Theater%20Festival">Great Lakes Theater Festival</a>, and the Tri-C Jazz Fest. A city with strong traditions in <a href="theatre">theater</a> and <a href="vaudeville">vaudeville</a>, Cleveland has produced many renowned performers, most prominently comedian <a href="Bob%20Hope">Bob Hope</a>.
Outside Playhouse Square, Cleveland is home to <a href="Karamu%20House">Karamu House</a>, the oldest African American theater in the nation, established in 1915. On the West Side, the Gordon Square Arts District in Detroit–Shoreway is the location of the Capitol Theatre, the <a href="Near%20West%20Theatre">Near West Theatre</a>, and an <a href="Off-Off-Broadway">Off-Off-Broadway</a> Playhouse, the <a href="Cleveland%20Public%20Theatre">Cleveland Public Theatre</a>. Cleveland's streetcar suburbs of Cleveland Heights and Lakewood are home to the <a href="Dobama%20Theatre">Dobama Theatre</a> and the <a href="Beck%20Center%20for%20the%20Arts">Beck Center for the Arts</a> respectively.
Cleveland is home to the Cleveland Orchestra, widely considered one of the world's finest orchestras, and often referred to as the finest in the nation. It is one of the "<a href="Big%20Five%20%28orchestras%29">Big Five</a>" major orchestras in the United States. The Cleveland Orchestra plays at Severance Hall in University Circle during the winter and at <a href="Blossom%20Music%20Center">Blossom Music Center</a> in <a href="Cuyahoga%20Falls%2C%20Ohio">Cuyahoga Falls</a> during the summer. The city is also home to the <a href="Cleveland%20Pops%20Orchestra">Cleveland Pops Orchestra</a>, the <a href="Cleveland%20Orchestra%20Youth%20Orchestra">Cleveland Youth Orchestra</a>, the <a href="Contemporary%20Youth%20Orchestra">Contemporary Youth Orchestra</a>, the <a href="Cleveland%20Youth%20Wind%20Symphony">Cleveland Youth Wind Symphony</a>, and the biennial <a href="Cleveland%20International%20Piano%20Competition">Cleveland International Piano Competition</a> which has, in the past, often featured The Cleveland Orchestra.
One Playhouse Square, now the headquarters for Cleveland's <a href="public%20broadcasting">public broadcasters</a>, was initially used as the broadcast studios of WJW (AM), where disc jockey Alan Freed first popularized the term "rock and roll". Cleveland gained a strong reputation in rock music in the 1960s and 1970s as a key breakout market for nationally promoted acts and performers. Its popularity in the city was so great that Billy Bass, the program director at the <a href="WMMS">WMMS</a> radio station, referred to Cleveland as "The Rock and Roll Capital of the World." The <a href="Agora%20Theatre%20and%20Ballroom">Cleveland Agora Theatre and Ballroom</a> has served as a major venue for rock concerts in the city since the 1960s. From 1974 through 1980, the city hosted the <a href="World%20Series%20of%20Rock">World Series of Rock</a> at <a href="Cleveland%20Stadium">Cleveland Municipal Stadium</a>.
Jazz and R&B have a long history in Cleveland. Many major figures in jazz, including <a href="Louis%20Armstrong">Louis Armstrong</a>, <a href="Cab%20Calloway">Cab Calloway</a>, <a href="Duke%20Ellington">Duke Ellington</a>, <a href="Ella%20Fitzgerald">Ella Fitzgerald</a>, <a href="Dizzy%20Gillespie">Dizzy Gillespie</a>, <a href="Benny%20Goodman">Benny Goodman</a>, <a href="Billie%20Holiday">Billie Holiday</a>, and <a href="Don%20Redman">Don Redman</a> performed in the city, and legendary pianist <a href="Art%20Tatum">Art Tatum</a> regularly played in Cleveland clubs during the 1930s. <a href="Gypsy%20jazz">Gypsy jazz</a> guitarist <a href="Django%20Reinhardt">Django Reinhardt</a> gave his U.S. debut performance in Cleveland in 1946. Prominent jazz artist <a href="Noble%20Sissle">Noble Sissle</a> was a graduate of <a href="Central%20High%20School%20%28Cleveland%2C%20Ohio%29">Cleveland Central High School</a>, <a href="Artie%20Shaw">Artie Shaw</a> worked and performed in Cleveland early in his career, and bandleader <a href="Phil%20Spitalny">Phil Spitalny</a> led his first orchestra in Cleveland. The Tri-C Jazz Fest has been held annually in Cleveland at Playhouse Square since 1979, and the Cleveland Jazz Orchestra was established in 1984. Joe Siebert's documentary film "The Sax Man" on the life of Cleveland street saxophonist <a href="Sax%20Man">Maurice Reedus Jr.</a> was released in 2014.
There is a significant <a href="hip%20hop%20music">hip hop music</a> scene in Cleveland. In 1997, the Cleveland hip hop group <a href="Bone%20Thugs-n-Harmony">Bone Thugs-n-Harmony</a> won a <a href="Grammy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Rap%20Performance%20by%20a%20Duo%20or%20Group">Grammy</a> for their song "<a href="Tha%20Crossroads">Tha Crossroads</a>".
The city also has a history of <a href="polka">polka</a> music being popular both past and present, even having a subgenre called <a href="Slovenian-style%20polka">Cleveland-style polka</a> named after the city, and is home to the <a href="Polka%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Polka Hall of Fame</a>. This is due in part to the success of <a href="Frankie%20Yankovic">Frankie Yankovic</a>, a Cleveland native who was considered "America's Polka King." The square at the intersection of Waterloo Road and East 152nd Street in Cleveland (), not far from where Yankovic grew up, was named in his honor.
Film and television.
Cleveland has served as the setting for many <a href="Major%20film%20studio">major studio</a> and <a href="Independent%20film">independent</a> films, and, early in <a href="Cinema%20of%20the%20United%20States">American film history</a>, it was even a center for film production. The first film shot in Cleveland was in 1897 by the <a href="Edison%20Manufacturing%20Company">Edison Company</a>. Before <a href="Hollywood">Hollywood</a> became the center for American cinema, filmmaker Samuel R. Brodsky and playwright Robert H. McLaughlin operated a studio at the <a href="Samuel%20Andrews%20%28chemist%29">Andrews</a> mansion on Euclid Avenue (now the <a href="WEWS-TV">WEWS-TV</a> studio). There they produced major <a href="silent%20film">silent-era</a> features, such as "<a href="Dangerous%20Toys%20%28film%29">Dangerous Toys</a>" (1921), which are now considered <a href="lost%20film">lost</a>. Brodsky also directed the weekly "Plain Dealer Screen Magazine" that ran in theaters in Cleveland and Ohio from 1917 to 1924.
In the "<a href="sound%20film">talkie</a>" era, Cleveland featured in numerous <a href="Classical%20Hollywood%20cinema">classic Hollywood movies</a>, such as <a href="Howard%20Hawks">Howard Hawks</a>'s "<a href="Ceiling%20Zero">Ceiling Zero</a>" (1936) with <a href="James%20Cagney">James Cagney</a> and <a href="Pat%20O%27Brien%20%28actor%29">Pat O'Brien</a>, and <a href="Hobart%20Henley">Hobart Henley</a>'s romantic comedy "<a href="The%20Big%20Pond">The Big Pond</a>" (1930) with <a href="Maurice%20Chevalier">Maurice Chevalier</a> and <a href="Claudette%20Colbert">Claudette Colbert</a>, which introduced the hit song "<a href="You%20Brought%20a%20New%20Kind%20of%20Love%20to%20Me">You Brought a New Kind of Love to Me</a>". <a href="Michael%20Curtiz">Michael Curtiz</a>'s 1933 <a href="Pre-Code%20Hollywood">pre-Code</a> classic "<a href="Goodbye%20Again%20%281933%20film%29">Goodbye Again</a>" with <a href="Warren%20William">Warren William</a> and <a href="Joan%20Blondell">Joan Blondell</a> was set in Cleveland. Players from the <a href="1948%20Cleveland%20Indians%20season">1948 Cleveland Indians</a>, winners of the <a href="1948%20World%20Series">World Series</a>, appeared in "<a href="The%20Kid%20from%20Cleveland">The Kid from Cleveland</a>" (1949). Cleveland Municipal Stadium features prominently in both that film and "<a href="The%20Fortune%20Cookie">The Fortune Cookie</a>" (1966). Written and directed by <a href="Billy%20Wilder">Billy Wilder</a>, the latter marked <a href="Walter%20Matthau">Walter Matthau</a> and <a href="Jack%20Lemmon">Jack Lemmon</a>'s first on-screen collaboration and features gameday <a href="footage">footage</a> of the <a href="1965%20Cleveland%20Browns%20season">1965 Browns</a>.
Other films set in Cleveland include <a href="Jules%20Dassin">Jules Dassin</a>'s "<a href="Up%20Tight%21">Up Tight!</a>" (1968) and <a href="Norman%20Jewison">Norman Jewison</a>'s "<a href="F.I.S.T.%20%28film%29">F.I.S.T.</a>" (1978), the latter featuring <a href="Sylvester%20Stallone">Sylvester Stallone</a> as a local union leader. <a href="Paul%20Simon">Paul Simon</a> chose Cleveland as the opening for his only venture into filmmaking, "<a href="One-Trick%20Pony%20%28film%29">One-Trick Pony</a>" (1980). Clevelander <a href="Jim%20Jarmusch">Jim Jarmusch</a>'s "<a href="Stranger%20Than%20Paradise">Stranger Than Paradise</a>" (1984)—a <a href="deadpan">deadpan</a> comedy about two New Yorkers who travel to Florida by way of Cleveland—was a favorite of the <a href="Cannes%20Film%20Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a>, winning the <a href="Cam%C3%A9ra%20d%27Or">Caméra d'Or</a>. Both "<a href="Major%20League%20%28film%29">Major League</a>" (1989) and "<a href="Major%20League%20II">Major League II</a>" (1994) reflected the of the Cleveland Indians during the 1960s, 1970s, and 1980s. Several key scenes from <a href="Cameron%20Crowe">Cameron Crowe</a>'s "<a href="Almost%20Famous">Almost Famous</a>" (2000) are set in Cleveland, and both "<a href="Antwone%20Fisher%20%28film%29">Antwone Fisher</a>" (2002) and "<a href="The%20Soloist">The Soloist</a>" (2009) recount the real-life stories of Cleveland natives. Brothers <a href="Joe%20Russo%20%28director%29">Joe</a> and <a href="Anthony%20Russo%20%28director%29">Anthony Russo</a>—native Clevelanders—filmed their comedy "<a href="Welcome%20to%20Collinwood">Welcome to Collinwood</a>" (2002) entirely <a href="Filming%20location">on location</a> in the city. "<a href="American%20Splendor%20%28film%29">American Splendor</a>" (2003)—the <a href="Biographical%20film">biopic</a> of <a href="Harvey%20Pekar">Harvey Pekar</a>, author of the <a href="American%20Splendor">autobiographical comic of the same name</a>—was also filmed in Cleveland. "<a href="Kill%20the%20Irishman">Kill the Irishman</a>" (2011) depicts the 1970s turf war in Cleveland between Irish mobster <a href="Danny%20Greene">Danny Greene</a> and the Cleveland crime family, while "<a href="Draft%20Day">Draft Day</a>" (2014) features <a href="Kevin%20Costner">Kevin Costner</a> as general manager for the Browns.
Cleveland has also doubled for other locations in films. The wedding and reception scenes in "<a href="The%20Deer%20Hunter">The Deer Hunter</a>" (1978), while set in the small Pittsburgh suburb of <a href="Clairton%2C%20Pennsylvania">Clairton</a>, were shot in Cleveland's Tremont; <a href="U.S.%20Steel">U.S. Steel</a> also permitted the production to film in one of its Cleveland mills. <a href="Francis%20Ford%20Coppola">Francis Ford Coppola</a> produced "<a href="The%20Escape%20Artist">The Escape Artist</a>" (1982), much of which was shot in Downtown Cleveland. "<a href="A%20Christmas%20Story">A Christmas Story</a>" (1983) was set in <a href="Indiana">Indiana</a>, but drew many of its external shots—including the Parker family home—from Cleveland. The opening shots of "<a href="Air%20Force%20One%20%28film%29">Air Force One</a>" (1997) were filmed in and above Severance Hall. Downtown Cleveland also doubled for New York in "<a href="Spider-Man%203">Spider-Man 3</a>" (2007) and the climax of "<a href="The%20Avengers%20%282012%20film%29">The Avengers</a>" (2012). More recently, "" (2014), "<a href="The%20Fate%20of%20the%20Furious">The Fate of the Furious</a>" (2017), and "<a href="Judas%20and%20the%20Black%20Messiah">Judas and the Black Messiah</a>" (2021) were all filmed in the city. Future Cleveland productions are handled by the <a href="Greater%20Cleveland%20Film%20Commission">Greater Cleveland Film Commission</a>.
In television, the city is the setting for the popular network sitcom "<a href="The%20Drew%20Carey%20Show">The Drew Carey Show</a>", starring Cleveland native <a href="Drew%20Carey">Drew Carey</a>. "<a href="Hot%20in%20Cleveland">Hot in Cleveland</a>", a comedy that aired on <a href="TV%20Land">TV Land</a>, premiered on June 16, 2010, and ran for six seasons until its finale on June 3, 2015. Later episodes of the reality show "<a href="Keeping%20Up%20With%20the%20Kardashians">Keeping Up With the Kardashians</a>" have been partially filmed in Cleveland, after series star <a href="Khloe%20Kardashian">Khloe Kardashian</a> began a relationship with Cleveland Cavaliers <a href="center%20%28basketball%29">center</a> <a href="Tristan%20Thompson">Tristan Thompson</a>. "<a href="Cleveland%20Hustles">Cleveland Hustles</a>", the <a href="CNBC">CNBC</a> reality show co-created by <a href="LeBron%20James">LeBron James</a>, was filmed in the city.
Literature.
<a href="Langston%20Hughes">Langston Hughes</a>, preeminent poet of the <a href="Harlem%20Renaissance">Harlem Renaissance</a> and child of an itinerant couple, lived in Cleveland as a teenager and attended Central High School in Cleveland in the 1910s. At Central High, Hughes was taught by <a href="Helen%20Maria%20Chesnutt">Helen Maria Chesnutt</a>, daughter of renowned Cleveland-born African American novelist <a href="Charles%20W.%20Chesnutt">Charles W. Chesnutt</a>. He also wrote for the school newspaper and started writing his earlier plays, poems and short stories while living in Cleveland. The African American avant-garde poet <a href="Russell%20Atkins">Russell Atkins</a> also lived in Cleveland.
The American modernist poet <a href="Hart%20Crane">Hart Crane</a> was born in nearby <a href="Garrettsville%2C%20Ohio">Garrettsville, Ohio</a> in 1899. His adolescence was divided between Cleveland and Akron before he moved to New York City in 1916. Aside from factory work during the first world war, he served as a reporter to "<a href="The%20Plain%20Dealer">The Plain Dealer</a>" for a short period, before achieving recognition in the <a href="Modernist">Modernist</a> literary scene. A diminutive memorial park is dedicated to Crane along the left bank of the Cuyahoga in Cleveland. In University Circle, a historical marker sits at the location of his Cleveland childhood house on E. 115 near the Euclid Avenue intersection. On the Case Western Reserve University campus, a statue of him, designed by sculptor <a href="William%20McVey%20%28sculptor%29">William McVey</a>, stands behind the Kelvin Smith Library.
Cleveland was the home of <a href="Joe%20Shuster">Joe Shuster</a> and <a href="Jerry%20Siegel">Jerry Siegel</a>, who created the comic book character <a href="Superman">Superman</a> in 1932. Both attended <a href="Glenville%20High%20School">Glenville High School</a>, and their early collaborations resulted in the creation of "The Man of Steel". <a href="Harlan%20Ellison">Harlan Ellison</a>, noted author of <a href="speculative%20fiction">speculative fiction</a>, was born in Cleveland in 1934; his family subsequently moved to the nearby town of <a href="Painesville%2C%20Ohio">Painesville</a>, though Ellison moved back to Cleveland in 1949. As a youngster, he published a series of short stories appearing in the "<a href="Cleveland%20Press">Cleveland News</a>"; he also performed in a number of productions for the Cleveland Play House. <a href="D.%20A.%20Levy">D. A. Levy</a> wrote: "Cleveland: The Rectal Eye Visions". Mystery author <a href="Richard%20Montanari">Richard Montanari</a>'s first three novels, "Deviant Way", "The Violet Hour", and "Kiss of Evil" are set in Cleveland. Mystery writer, <a href="Les%20Roberts%20%28mystery%20novel%20writer%29">Les Roberts</a>'s "Milan Jacovich" series is also set in Cleveland. Author and Ohio resident, <a href="James%20Renner">James Renner</a> set his <a href="debut%20novel">debut novel</a>, "The Man from Primrose Lane" in present-day Cleveland.
The <a href="Cleveland%20State%20University%20Poetry%20Center">Cleveland State University Poetry Center</a> serves as an academic center for poetry. Cleveland continues to have a thriving literary and poetry community, with regular poetry readings at bookstores, coffee shops, and various other venues.
Cleveland is the site of the <a href="Anisfield-Wolf%20Book%20Award">Anisfield-Wolf Book Award</a>, established by poet and philanthropist <a href="Edith%20Anisfield%20Wolf">Edith Anisfield Wolf</a> in 1935, which recognizes books that have made important contributions to the understanding of racism and human diversity. Presented by the Cleveland Foundation, it remains the only American book prize focusing on works that address racism and diversity. In an early <a href="Gay%20and%20lesbian%20studies">Gay and lesbian studies</a> anthology titled Lavender Culture, a short piece by John Kelsey "The Cleveland Bar Scene in the Forties" discusses the gay and lesbian culture in Cleveland and the unique experiences of amateur female impersonators that existed alongside the New York and San Francisco <a href="LGBT">LGBT</a> subcultures.
Museums and galleries.
Cleveland has two main <a href="art%20museum">art museum</a>s. The Cleveland Museum of Art is a major American art museum, with a collection that includes more than 40,000 works of art ranging over 6,000 years, from <a href="ancient%20art">ancient masterpieces</a> to <a href="contemporary%20art">contemporary pieces</a>. The <a href="Museum%20of%20Contemporary%20Art%20Cleveland">Museum of Contemporary Art Cleveland</a> showcases established and emerging artists, particularly from the Cleveland area, through hosting and producing temporary exhibitions. Both museums offer free admission to visitors, with the Cleveland Museum of Art declaring their museum free and open "for the benefit of all the people forever."
Both museums are also part of Cleveland's University Circle, a concentration of cultural, educational, and medical institutions located east of downtown. In addition to the art museums, the neighborhood also includes the Cleveland Botanical Garden, Case Western Reserve University, University Hospitals, Severance Hall, the <a href="Cleveland%20Museum%20of%20Natural%20History">Cleveland Museum of Natural History</a>, and the <a href="Western%20Reserve%20Historical%20Society">Western Reserve Historical Society</a>. Also located at University Circle is the <a href="Cleveland%20Cinematheque">Cleveland Cinematheque</a> at the Cleveland Institute of Art, hailed by "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>" as one of the country's best alternative movie theaters.
Cleveland is home to the <a href="I.%20M.%20Pei">I. M. Pei</a>-designed Rock and Roll Hall of Fame on the Lake Erie waterfront at North Coast Harbor downtown. Neighboring attractions include FirstEnergy Stadium, the Great Lakes Science Center, the <a href="SS%20William%20G.%20Mather%20%281925%29">Steamship Mather Museum</a>, and the , a World War II <a href="Gato-class%20submarine">submarine</a>. Designed by architect <a href="Levi%20Scofield">Levi T. Scofield</a>, the Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument at Public Square is Cleveland's major Civil War memorial and a major attraction in the city. Other city attractions include the Lorenzo Carter Cabin, the <a href="Grays%20Armory">Grays Armory</a>, the Cleveland Police Museum, and the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland's Money Museum. A Cleveland holiday attraction, especially for fans of <a href="Jean%20Shepherd">Jean Shepherd</a>'s "A Christmas Story", is the <a href="A%20Christmas%20Story%20House">Christmas Story House and Museum</a> in Tremont.
Events.
The Cleveland International Film Festival has been held annually since 1977, and it drew a record 106,000 people in 2017. <a href="Fashion%20Week%20Cleveland">Fashion Week Cleveland</a>, the city's annual fashion event, is the third-largest fashion show of its kind in the United States. The <a href="Cleveland%20National%20Air%20Show">Cleveland National Air Show</a>, an indirect successor to the <a href="National%20Air%20Races">National Air Races</a>, has been annually held at the city's <a href="Burke%20Lakefront%20Airport">Burke Lakefront Airport</a> since 1964. Sponsored by the Great Lakes Brewing Company, the Great Lakes Burning River Fest, a two-night music and beer festival at Whiskey Island, has been held annually since 2001. Proceeds from that festival benefit the Burning River Foundation, a local non-profit dedicated to "improving, maintaining and celebrating the vitality of [Cleveland's] regional freshwater resources." Cleveland also hosts an annual holiday display lighting and celebration, dubbed Winterfest, which is held downtown at the city's historic hub, Public Square.
Cuisine.
Cleveland's mosaic of ethnic communities and their various culinary traditions have long played an important role in defining the local cuisine. Examples of these can particularly be found in neighborhoods such as <a href="Little%20Italy%2C%20Cleveland">Little Italy</a>, <a href="Slavic%20Village">Slavic Village</a>, and Tremont.
Local mainstays of Cleveland's cuisine include an abundance of Polish and Central European contributions, such as <a href="kielbasa">kielbasa</a>, <a href="stuffed%20cabbage">stuffed cabbage</a> and <a href="pierogi">pierogi</a>es. Cleveland also has plenty of <a href="corned%20beef">corned beef</a>, with nationally renowned Slyman's, on the near East Side, a perennial winner of various accolades from "<a href="Esquire%20Magazine">Esquire Magazine</a>", including being named the best corned beef sandwich in America in 2008. Other famed sandwiches include the Cleveland original, <a href="Polish%20Boy">Polish Boy</a>, a local favorite found at many BBQ and Soul food restaurants. With its <a href="Blue-collar%20worker">blue-collar</a> roots well intact, and plenty of Lake Erie <a href="Yellow%20perch">perch</a> available, the tradition of Friday night <a href="fish%20fry">fish fries</a> remains alive and thriving in Cleveland, particularly in church-based settings and during the season of Lent. 
Cleveland is noted in the world of celebrity food culture. Famous local figures include chef <a href="Michael%20Symon">Michael Symon</a> and <a href="food%20critic">food writer</a> <a href="Michael%20Ruhlman">Michael Ruhlman</a>, both of whom achieved local and national attention for their contributions to the culinary world. On November 11, 2007, Symon helped gain the spotlight when he was named "<a href="The%20Next%20Iron%20Chef">The Next Iron Chef</a>" on the <a href="Food%20Network">Food Network</a>. In 2007, Ruhlman collaborated with <a href="Anthony%20Bourdain">Anthony Bourdain</a>, to do an episode of his "" focusing on Cleveland's restaurant scene.
The national food press—including publications "Gourmet", "Food & Wine", "Esquire" and "Playboy"—has heaped praise on several Cleveland spots for awards including 'best new restaurant', 'best steakhouse', 'best farm-to-table programs' and 'great new neighborhood eateries'. In early 2008, the "<a href="Chicago%20Tribune">Chicago Tribune</a>" ran a feature article in its 'Travel' section proclaiming Cleveland, America's "hot new dining city". In 2015, the city was named the 7th best food city in the nation by "<a href="Time%20%28magazine%29">Time</a>" magazine.
Breweries.
Ohio produces the fifth most amount of beer in the United States, with its largest brewery being Cleveland's <a href="Great%20Lakes%20Brewing%20Company">Great Lakes Brewing Company</a>. Cleveland has had a long history of brewing, tied to many of its ethnic immigrants, and in recent decades has reemerged as a regional leader in production. In modern times, dozens of breweries exist in the city limits, including large producers such as <a href="Market%20Garden%20Brewery">Market Garden Brewery</a> and <a href="Platform%20Beer%20Company">Platform Beer Company</a>.
Breweries can be found throughout the city, but the highest concentration is in the <a href="Ohio%20City%2C%20Cleveland">Ohio City</a> neighborhood. Cleveland is also home to expansions from other countries, including the Scottish <a href="BrewDog">BrewDog</a> and German <a href="Staatliches_Hofbr%C3%A4uhaus_in_M%C3%BCnchen%23Franchises">Hofbrauhaus</a>.
Sports.
Cleveland's current major professional sports teams include the <a href="Cleveland%20Guardians">Cleveland Guardians</a> (<a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a>), the <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a> (<a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a>), the <a href="Cleveland%20Cavaliers">Cleveland Cavaliers</a> (<a href="National%20Basketball%20Association">National Basketball Association</a>), the <a href="Cleveland%20Crunch">Cleveland Crunch</a> (<a href="Major%20Arena%20Soccer%20League%202">Major Arena Soccer League 2</a>) and the <a href="Cleveland%20Monsters">Cleveland Monsters</a> (<a href="American%20Hockey%20League">American Hockey League</a>). Local sporting facilities include <a href="Progressive%20Field">Progressive Field</a>, <a href="FirstEnergy%20Stadium">FirstEnergy Stadium</a>, <a href="Rocket%20Mortgage%20FieldHouse">Rocket Mortgage FieldHouse</a>. The <a href="Cleveland%20Monsters">Cleveland Monsters</a> of the <a href="American%20Hockey%20League">American Hockey League</a> won the <a href="2016%20Calder%20Cup%20playoffs">2016 Calder Cup</a>, the first Cleveland AHL team to do so since the <a href="1963%E2%80%9364%20AHL%20season">1964</a> Barons. The Cleveland Guardians, known as the Indians from 1915 to 2021, won the <a href="World%20Series">World Series</a> in <a href="1920%20World%20Series">1920</a> and <a href="1948%20World%20Series">1948</a>. They also won the <a href="American%20League">American League</a> pennant, making the World Series in the <a href="1954%20World%20Series">1954</a>, <a href="1995%20World%20Series">1995</a>, <a href="1997%20World%20Series">1997</a>, and <a href="2016%20World%20Series">2016</a> seasons. Between <a href="1995%20MLB%20season">1995</a> and <a href="2001%20MLB%20season">2001</a>, Progressive Field (then known as Jacobs Field) sold out 455 consecutive games, a Major League Baseball record until it was broken in 2008.
Historically, the Browns have been among the most successful franchises in <a href="American%20football">American football</a> history, winning eight titles during a short period of time—<a href="1946%20Cleveland%20Browns%20season">1946</a>, <a href="1947%20Cleveland%20Browns%20season">1947</a>, <a href="1948%20Cleveland%20Browns%20season">1948</a>, <a href="1949%20Cleveland%20Browns%20season">1949</a>, <a href="1950%20NFL%20Championship%20Game">1950</a>, <a href="1954%20NFL%20Championship%20Game">1954</a>, <a href="1955%20NFL%20Championship%20Game">1955</a>, and <a href="1964%20NFL%20Championship%20Game">1964</a>. Former owner <a href="Art%20Modell">Art Modell</a>'s <a href="Cleveland%20Browns%20relocation%20controversy">relocation of the Browns</a> after the <a href="1995%20NFL%20season">1995 season</a> (to <a href="Baltimore">Baltimore</a> creating the <a href="Baltimore%20Ravens">Ravens</a>), caused tremendous heartbreak and resentment among local fans. Cleveland mayor, <a href="Michael%20R.%20White">Michael R. White</a>, worked with the NFL and Commissioner <a href="Paul%20Tagliabue">Paul Tagliabue</a> to bring back the Browns beginning in the <a href="1999%20NFL%20season">1999 season</a>, retaining all team history. In Cleveland's earlier football history, the <a href="Cleveland%20Bulldogs">Cleveland Bulldogs</a> won the <a href="NFL%20Championship">NFL Championship</a> in <a href="1924%20NFL%20season">1924</a>, and the <a href="History%20of%20the%20Cleveland%20Rams">Cleveland Rams</a> won the NFL Championship in <a href="1945%20NFL%20season">1945</a> before relocating to <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a>.
The Cavaliers won the <a href="Eastern%20Conference%20%28NBA%29">Eastern Conference</a> in <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20NBA%20season">2007</a>, <a href="2014%E2%80%9315%20NBA%20season">2015</a>, <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20NBA%20season">2016</a>, <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20NBA%20season">2017</a> and <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20NBA%20season">2018</a> but were defeated in the <a href="2007%20NBA%20Finals">NBA Finals</a> by the <a href="San%20Antonio%20Spurs">San Antonio Spurs</a> and <a href="2015%20NBA%20Finals">then by</a> the Golden State Warriors, respectively. The Cavs won the Conference again in 2016 and won their first NBA Championship coming back from a 3–1 deficit, finally defeating the <a href="Golden%20State%20Warriors">Golden State Warriors</a>. Afterwards, an estimated 1.3 million people attended a parade held in the Cavs honor on June 22, 2016. This was the first time the city had planned for a championship parade in 50 years. Previously, the <a href="Cleveland%20Rosenblums">Cleveland Rosenblums</a> dominated the original <a href="American%20Basketball%20League%20%281925%E2%80%9355%29">American Basketball League</a> winning three of the first five championships (1926, 1929, 1930), and the <a href="Cleveland%20Pipers">Cleveland Pipers</a>, owned by <a href="George%20Steinbrenner">George Steinbrenner</a>, won the <a href="American%20Basketball%20League%20%281961%E2%80%9363%29">American Basketball League</a> championship in 1962.
<a href="Jesse%20Owens">Jesse Owens</a> grew up in Cleveland after moving from <a href="Alabama">Alabama</a> when he was nine. He participated in the <a href="1936%20Summer%20Olympics">1936 Summer Olympics</a> in Berlin, where he achieved international fame by winning four <a href="gold%20medal">gold medal</a>s. A statue commemorating his achievement can be found in Downtown Cleveland at Fort Washington Park. A statue of another famous Cleveland athlete, Irish American World Featherweight <a href="boxing">boxing</a> champion <a href="Johnny%20Kilbane">Johnny Kilbane</a>, stands in the city's Battery Park on the West Side.
Cleveland State University alum and area native <a href="Stipe%20Miocic">Stipe Miocic</a> won the <a href="Ultimate%20Fighting%20Championship">UFC</a> World Heavyweight Championship at <a href="UFC%20198">UFC 198</a> in 2016. Miocic has defended his World Heavyweight Champion title at <a href="UFC%20203">UFC 203</a>, the first ever UFC World Championship fight held in the city of Cleveland, and again at <a href="UFC%20211">UFC 211</a> and <a href="UFC%20220">UFC 220</a>. After losing it in 2018, Miocic regained the world title at <a href="UFC%20241">UFC 241</a>.
Collegiately, <a href="NCAA%20Division%20I">NCAA Division I</a> <a href="Cleveland%20State%20Vikings">Cleveland State Vikings</a> have 16 varsity sports, nationally known for their <a href="Cleveland%20State%20Vikings%20men%27s%20basketball">Cleveland State Vikings men's basketball</a> team. <a href="NCAA%20Division%20III">NCAA Division III</a> <a href="Case%20Western%20Reserve%20Spartans">Case Western Reserve Spartans</a> have 19 varsity sports, most known for their <a href="Case%20Western%20Reserve%20Spartans%20football">Case Western Reserve Spartans football</a> team.
