The conference also stages both its <a href="Mid-American%20Conference%20Men%27s%20Basketball%20Tournament">men's</a> and <a href="Mid-American%20Conference%20Women%27s%20Basketball%20Tournament">women's</a> basketball tournaments at Rocket Mortgage FieldHouse.
Several chess championships have taken place in Cleveland. The second <a href="American%20Chess%20Congress">American Chess Congress</a>, a predecessor the current U.S. Championship, was held in 1871, and won by <a href="George%20Henry%20Mackenzie">George Henry Mackenzie</a>. The 1921 and 1957 <a href="U.S.%20Open%20Chess%20Championship">U.S. Open Chess Championship</a> also took place in the city, and were won by <a href="Edward%20Lasker">Edward Lasker</a> and <a href="Bobby%20Fischer">Bobby Fischer</a>, respectively. The <a href="Cleveland%20Open%20%28chess%29">Cleveland Open</a> is held annually.
The <a href="Cleveland%20Marathon">Cleveland Marathon</a> has been hosted annually since 1978.
Environment.
With its extensive cleanup of its Lake Erie shore and the Cuyahoga River, Cleveland has been recognized by national media as an environmental success story and a national leader in environmental protection. Since the city's industrialization, the Cuyahoga River had become so affected by industrial pollution that it "caught fire" a total of 13 times beginning in 1868. It was the river fire of June 1969 that spurred the city to action under Mayor Carl B. Stokes, and played a key role in the passage of the <a href="Clean%20Water%20Act">Clean Water Act</a> in 1972 and the <a href="National%20Environmental%20Policy%20Act">National Environmental Policy Act</a> later that year. Since that time, the Cuyahoga has been extensively cleaned up through the efforts of the city and the <a href="Ohio%20Environmental%20Protection%20Agency">Ohio Environmental Protection Agency</a> (OEPA). In 2019, the American Rivers conservation association named the river "River of the Year" in honor of "50 years of environmental resurgence."
In addition to continued efforts to improve freshwater and air quality, Cleveland is now exploring renewable energy. The city's two main electrical utilities are <a href="FirstEnergy">FirstEnergy</a> and <a href="Cleveland%20Public%20Power">Cleveland Public Power</a>. Its <a href="List%20of%20climate%20change%20initiatives">climate action plan</a>, updated in December 2018, has a 2050 target of 100 percent <a href="Renewable%20energy">renewable power</a>, along with reduction of <a href="Greenhouse%20gas%20emissions%20by%20the%20United%20States">greenhouse gases</a> to 80 percent below the 2010 level. In recent years, Cleveland has also been working to address the issue of <a href="harmful%20algal%20bloom">harmful</a> <a href="algal%20bloom">algal bloom</a>s on Lake Erie, fed primarily by agricultural runoff, which have presented new environmental challenges for the city and for northern Ohio.
Government and politics.
Cleveland operates on a <a href="Strong-mayor">mayor–council (strong mayor)</a> form of government, in which the mayor is the <a href="executive%20%28government%29">chief executive</a>. From 1924 to 1931, the city briefly experimented with a <a href="council%E2%80%93manager%20government">council–manager government</a> under <a href="William%20R.%20Hopkins">William R. Hopkins</a> and <a href="Daniel%20E.%20Morgan">Daniel E. Morgan</a> before returning to the mayor–council system.
The office of the mayor has been held by <a href="Justin%20Bibb">Justin Bibb</a> since 2022. Previous mayors of Cleveland include progressive Democrat Tom L. Johnson, <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>-era <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20War">War Secretary</a> and <a href="BakerHostetler">BakerHostetler</a> founder <a href="Newton%20D.%20Baker">Newton D. Baker</a>, <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20the%20United%20States">U.S. Supreme Court</a> <a href="Associate%20Justice%20of%20the%20Supreme%20Court%20of%20the%20United%20States">Justice</a> <a href="Harold%20Hitz%20Burton">Harold Hitz Burton</a>, two-term Ohio Governor and <a href="United%20States%20Senate">Senator</a> <a href="Frank%20J.%20Lausche">Frank J. Lausche</a>, former <a href="United%20States%20Secretary%20of%20Health%20and%20Human%20Services">U.S. Health, Education, and Welfare Secretary</a> <a href="Anthony%20J.%20Celebrezze">Anthony J. Celebrezze</a>, two-term Ohio Governor and Senator George V. Voinovich, former U.S. Congressman Dennis Kucinich, and <a href="Carl%20B.%20Stokes">Carl B. Stokes</a>, the first African American mayor of a major U.S. city.
The Cleveland City Council is lead by Council President Blaine Griffin. The city is broken up into 17 wards. Currently all 17 wards are represented by Democrats. The current majority leader of the council is Kerry McCormack. 
Another nationally prominent Ohio politician, former U.S. President <a href="James%20A.%20Garfield">James A. Garfield</a>, was born in Cuyahoga County's <a href="Defunct%20townships%20of%20Cuyahoga%20County%2C%20Ohio">Orange Township</a> (today the Cleveland suburb of <a href="Moreland%20Hills%2C%20Ohio">Moreland Hills</a>). His resting place is the <a href="James%20A.%20Garfield%20Memorial">James A. Garfield Memorial</a> in Cleveland's <a href="Lake%20View%20Cemetery">Lake View Cemetery</a>.
From the Civil War era to the 1940s, Cleveland was primarily dominated by the <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican Party</a>, with the notable exceptions of the Johnson and Baker mayoral administrations. Businessman and Senator Mark Hanna was among Cleveland's most influential Republican figures, both locally and nationally. In addition to the established support of organized labor, the Cuyahoga County <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democratic Party</a>, led by former mayor <a href="Ray%20T.%20Miller">Ray T. Miller</a>, was able to secure the support of the city's ethnic European and African American communities in the 1940s. Beginning with the Lausche administration, Cleveland's political orientation shifted to the Democratic Party and, with the exceptions of the <a href="Ralph%20Perk">Perk</a> and Voinovich administrations, it has remained dominated by the Democrats ever since.
Today, while other parts of Ohio, particularly Cincinnati and the southern portion of the state, support the Republicans, Cleveland commonly produces the strongest support in the state for the Democrats. At the local level, elections are nonpartisan. However, Democrats still dominate every level of government. During the <a href="2004%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">2004 Presidential election</a>, although <a href="George%20W.%20Bush">George W. Bush</a> carried Ohio by 2.1%, <a href="John%20Kerry">John Kerry</a> carried Cuyahoga County 66.6%–32.9%, his largest margin in any Ohio county. The city of Cleveland supported Kerry over Bush by the even larger margin of 83.3%–15.8%. As a result of the 2010 Census, Ohio lost two Congressional seats, which affected Cleveland's districts in the northeast part of the state. Today, Cleveland is split between two <a href="List%20of%20United%20States%20congressional%20districts">congressional districts</a>. Most of the western part of the city is in the <a href="Ohio%27s%209th%20congressional%20district">9th District</a>, represented by <a href="Marcy%20Kaptur">Marcy Kaptur</a>. Most of the eastern part of the city, as well as most of downtown, is in the <a href="Ohio%27s%2011th%20congressional%20district">11th District</a>, represented by <a href="Shontel%20Brown">Shontel Brown</a>. Both are Democrats, two of four representing Ohio.
Cleveland hosted three Republican <a href="United%20States%20presidential%20nominating%20convention">national conventions</a> in its history, in <a href="1924%20Republican%20National%20Convention">1924</a>, <a href="1936%20Republican%20National%20Convention">1936</a>, and <a href="2016%20Republican%20National%20Convention">2016</a>. The city also hosted the <a href="Radical%20Republicans">Radical Republican</a> <a href="Radical%20Democracy%20Party%20%28United%20States%29%23Cleveland%20convention">convention of 1864</a>. Cleveland has not hosted a national convention for the Democrats, despite the position of Cuyahoga County as a Democratic stronghold in Ohio.
Cleveland has hosted several national election debates, including the <a href="1980%20United%20States%20presidential%20debates%23Second%20presidential%20debate%20%28Music%20Hall%29">second 1980 U.S. Presidential debate</a>, the , one , and the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20presidential%20debates%23September%2029%20presidential%20debate%20%28Case%20Western%20Reserve%20University%29">first 2020 U.S. Presidential debate</a>. Founded in 1912, the <a href="City%20Club%20of%20Cleveland">City Club of Cleveland</a> provides a platform for national and local debates and discussions. Known as Cleveland's "Citadel of Free Speech," it is one of the oldest continuous independent free speech and debate forums in the country.
Public safety.
Police and law enforcement.
Like in other major American cities, crime in Cleveland is concentrated in areas with higher rates of poverty and lower access to jobs. In recent years, the rate of crime in the city has seen a significant decline, following a nationwide trend in falling crime rates. Cleveland Police statistics published in 2019 showed that rates for violent crimes and property crimes in Cleveland dropped substantially in 2018. The rate of property crimes specifically fell by 30% since 2016.
Cleveland's law enforcement agency is the Cleveland Division of Police, established in 1866. The division has 1,444 sworn officers as of 2016. Cleveland has five police districts. The district system was introduced in the 1930s by Cleveland Public Safety Director <a href="Eliot%20Ness">Eliot Ness</a> (of the <a href="Untouchables%20%28law%20enforcement%29">Untouchables</a>), who later <a href="1947%20Cleveland%20mayoral%20election">ran for mayor of Cleveland</a> in 1947. The division has been recognized for several "firsts," including the "first criminal conviction secured by matching a palm print lifted from a crime scene to a suspect." The current <a href="chief%20of%20police">Chief of Police</a> is Calvin D. Williams.
In December 2014, the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20Justice">United States Department of Justice</a> announced the findings of a two-year investigation, prompted by a request from Mayor Frank Jackson, to determine whether the Cleveland Police engaged in a pattern of excessive force. As a result of the Justice Department report, the city agreed to a consent decree to revise its policies and implement new independent oversight over the police force. The consent decree, released on May 26, 2015, mandated sweeping changes to the Cleveland Police. On June 12, 2015, Chief U.S. District Judge <a href="Solomon%20Oliver%20Jr.">Solomon Oliver Jr.</a> approved and signed the consent decree, beginning the process of police reform.
Fire department.
Cleveland is served by the <a href="firefighter">firefighter</a>s of the Cleveland Division of Fire, established in 1863. The fire department operates out of 22 active fire stations throughout the city in five battalions. Each Battalion is commanded by a Battalion Chief, who reports to an on-duty Assistant Chief.
The Division of Fire operates a <a href="fire%20apparatus">fire apparatus</a> fleet of twenty-two engine companies, eight ladder companies, three tower companies, two task force <a href="rescue%20squad">rescue squad</a> companies, hazardous materials ("haz-mat") unit, and numerous other special, support, and reserve units. The current <a href="fire%20chief">Chief of Department</a> is Angelo Calvillo.
Emergency Medical Services.
Cleveland EMS is operated by the city as its own municipal third-service EMS division. Cleveland EMS is the primary provider of <a href="Advanced%20Life%20Support">Advanced Life Support</a> and ambulance transport within the city of Cleveland, while Cleveland Fire assists by providing fire response medical care. Although a merger between the fire and EMS departments was proposed in the past, the idea was subsequently abandoned.
Media.
Print.
Cleveland's primary daily newspaper is "<a href="The%20Plain%20Dealer">The Plain Dealer</a>" and its associated online publication, "Cleveland.com". Defunct major newspapers include the "<a href="Cleveland%20Press">Cleveland Press</a>", an afternoon publication which printed its last edition on June 17, 1982; and the "<a href="Cleveland%20News">Cleveland News</a>", which ceased publication in 1960. Additional publications include: the "<a href="Cleveland%20Magazine">Cleveland Magazine</a>", a regional culture magazine published monthly; "<a href="Crain%20Communications">Crain's Cleveland Business</a>", a weekly business newspaper; and "<a href="Cleveland%20Scene">Cleveland Scene</a>", a free <a href="Alternative%20newspaper">alternative weekly</a> paper which absorbed its competitor, the "<a href="Cleveland%20Free%20Times">Cleveland Free Times</a>", in 2008. Nationally distributed <a href="rock%20music">rock</a> <a href="Music%20magazine">magazine</a> "<a href="Alternative%20Press%20%28magazine%29">Alternative Press</a>" was founded in Cleveland in 1985, and the publication's headquarters remain in the city. The digital "<a href="Belt%20Magazine">Belt Magazine</a>" was founded in Cleveland in 2013. "<a href="Time%20%28magazine%29">Time</a>" magazine was published in Cleveland for a brief period from 1925 to 1927.
Cleveland's ethnic publications include: the "<a href="Call%20and%20Post">Call and Post</a>", a weekly newspaper that primarily serves the city's African American community; the "<a href="Cleveland%20Jewish%20News">Cleveland Jewish News</a>", a weekly <a href="Jewish%20newspaper">Jewish newspaper</a>; the bi-weekly <a href="Russian%20language">Russian language</a> "Cleveland Russian Magazine" for the Russian and post-Soviet community; the <a href="Chinese%20language">Mandarin</a> "Erie Chinese Journal" for the city's Chinese community; "La Gazzetta Italiana" in English and <a href="Italian%20language">Italian</a> for the Italian community; the "Ohio Irish American News" for the Irish community; and the <a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish language</a> "Vocero Latino News" for the Latino community. Historically, the <a href="Hungarian%20language">Hungarian language</a> newspaper "Szabadság" served the Hungarian community.
Television.
Cleveland is the 19th-largest television market by <a href="Nielsen%20Media%20Research">Nielsen Media Research</a> (–14). The market is served by 11 full power stations, including: WEWS-TV (<a href="American%20Broadcasting%20Company">ABC</a>), <a href="WJW%20%28TV%29">WJW</a> (<a href="Fox%20Broadcasting%20Company">Fox</a>), <a href="WKYC">WKYC</a> (<a href="NBC">NBC</a>), <a href="WOIO">WOIO</a> (<a href="CBS">CBS</a>), <a href="WVIZ">WVIZ</a> (<a href="PBS">PBS</a>), <a href="WUAB">WUAB</a> (<a href="The%20CW">The CW</a>), <a href="WVPX-TV">WVPX-TV</a> (<a href="Ion%20Television">Ion</a>), <a href="WQHS-DT">WQHS-DT</a> (<a href="Univision">Univision</a>), <a href="WDLI-TV">WDLI-TV</a> (<a href="Court%20TV">Court TV</a>), <a href="WRLM%20%28TV%29">WRLM</a> (<a href="Tri-State%20Christian%20Television">TCT</a>), and the independent <a href="WBNX-TV">WBNX-TV</a>.
"<a href="The%20Mike%20Douglas%20Show">The Mike Douglas Show</a>", a nationally <a href="Broadcast%20syndication">syndicated</a> <a href="Daytime%20television">daytime</a> talk show, began in Cleveland in 1961 on KYW-TV (now WKYC), while "<a href="The%20Morning%20Exchange">The Morning Exchange</a>" on WEWS-TV served as the model for "<a href="Good%20Morning%20America">Good Morning America</a>". <a href="Tim%20Conway">Tim Conway</a> and <a href="Ernie%20Anderson">Ernie Anderson</a> first established themselves in Cleveland while working together at KYW-TV and later WJW-TV (now WJW). Anderson both created and performed as the immensely popular Cleveland <a href="horror%20host">horror host</a> <a href="Ghoulardi">Ghoulardi</a> on WJW-TV's "Shock Theater", and was later succeeded by the long-running <a href="Late%20night%20television">late night</a> duo <a href="Big%20Chuck%20and%20Lil%27%20John">Big Chuck and Lil' John</a>.
Radio.
Cleveland is directly served by 32 <a href="AM%20broadcasting">AM</a> and <a href="FM%20broadcasting">FM</a> <a href="Radio%20broadcasting">radio stations</a>, 22 of which are licensed to the city. Commercial FM music stations are frequently the highest-rated stations in the market: <a href="WAKS">WAKS</a> (<a href="contemporary%20hit%20radio">contemporary hit radio</a>), <a href="WDOK">WDOK</a> (<a href="Adult%20contemporary%20music">adult contemporary</a>), <a href="WENZ">WENZ</a> (<a href="mainstream%20urban">mainstream urban</a>), <a href="WGAR-FM">WGAR-FM</a> (<a href="Country%20music">country</a>), <a href="WHLK">WHLK</a> (<a href="adult%20hits">adult hits</a>), <a href="WMJI">WMJI</a> (<a href="classic%20hits">classic hits</a>), <a href="WMMS">WMMS</a> (<a href="active%20rock">active rock</a>/<a href="hot%20talk">hot talk</a>), <a href="WNCX">WNCX</a> (<a href="classic%20rock">classic rock</a>), <a href="WNWV">WNWV</a> (<a href="alternative%20rock">alternative rock</a>), <a href="WQAL">WQAL</a> (<a href="hot%20adult%20contemporary">hot adult contemporary</a>), and <a href="WZAK">WZAK</a> (<a href="urban%20adult%20contemporary">urban adult contemporary</a>). <a href="WKSU">WKSU</a> <a href="Public%20broadcasting%23Radio">public radio</a> functions as the local <a href="NPR">NPR</a> <a href="Network%20affiliate">affiliate</a>, and <a href="sister%20station">sister station</a> <a href="WCLV">WCLV</a> airs a classical music format. <a href="Campus%20radio">College radio</a> stations include <a href="WBWC">WBWC</a> (Baldwin Wallace University), <a href="WCSB%20%28FM%29">WCSB</a> (Cleveland State University), <a href="WJCU">WJCU</a> (John Carroll University), and <a href="WRUW-FM">WRUW-FM</a> (Case Western Reserve University).
<a href="All-news%20radio">News</a>/<a href="Talk%20radio">talk</a> station <a href="WTAM">WTAM</a> serves as the AM <a href="Flagship%20%28broadcasting%29">flagship</a> for both the Cleveland Cavaliers and Cleveland Guardians. Sports oriented stations include WKNR (<a href="ESPN%20Radio">ESPN Radio</a>), <a href="WARF">WARF</a> (<a href="Fox%20Sports%20Radio">Fox Sports Radio</a>) and <a href="WKRK-FM">WKRK-FM</a> (<a href="CBS%20Sports%20Radio">CBS Sports Radio</a>). WKNR and WKRK-FM are also co-flagship stations for the Cleveland Browns. As WJW (AM), WKNR was once the home of Alan Freed − the Cleveland disc jockey credited with first using and popularizing the term "rock and roll" to describe the music genre. News/talk station <a href="WHK%20%28AM%29">WHK</a> was one of the first radio stations to broadcast in the United States and the first in Ohio. Its former sister station, rock station WMMS, dominated Cleveland radio in the 1970s and 1980s and was at that time one of the highest-rated radio stations in the country. In 1972, WMMS program director Billy Bass coined the phrase "The Rock and Roll Capital of the World" to describe Cleveland. In 1987, "<a href="Playboy">Playboy</a>" named WMMS DJ <a href="Kid%20Leo">Kid Leo</a> (Lawrence Travagliante) "The Best Disc Jockey in the Country".
Healthcare.
Cleveland is home to a number of leading hospital systems, several of which are in University Circle. Most notable is the world-renowned Cleveland Clinic, currently led by <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>n-born president and CEO Tomislav Mihaljevic. The clinic is affiliated with <a href="Case%20Western%20Reserve%20University%20School%20of%20Medicine">Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine</a>. The other major hospital in Cleveland is <a href="University%20Hospitals%20Cleveland%20Medical%20Center">University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center</a> with its <a href="Rainbow%20Babies%20%26amp%3B%20Children%27s%20Hospital">Rainbow Babies & Children's Hospital</a>. Cliff Megerian serves as that system's CEO. On the city's West Side is the main campus of the <a href="MetroHealth">MetroHealth System</a>, led by president and CEO Akram Boutros. Formerly known as City Hospital, MetroHealth operates one of two Level I trauma centers in the city, and has various locations throughout Greater Cleveland. Founded in 1865, the <a href="St.%20Vincent%20Charity%20Medical%20Center">St. Vincent Charity Medical Center</a>, led by CEO and president Janet Murphy, is the oldest hospital in the city.
In 2013, Cleveland's <a href="Global%20Center%20for%20Health%20Innovation">Global Center for Health Innovation</a> opened with of display space for healthcare companies across the world. To take advantage of the proximity of universities and other medical centers in Cleveland, the <a href="Veterans%20Administration">Veterans Administration</a> moved the region's VA hospital from suburban <a href="Brecksville">Brecksville</a> to a new facility in University Circle.
During the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic%20in%20the%20United%20States">2020 COVID-19 pandemic in the United States</a>, Ohio Governor <a href="Mike%20DeWine">Mike DeWine</a> reported the earliest cases of the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic%20in%20Ohio">virus in the state</a> to be in the Greater Cleveland Metropolitan Area, specifically Cuyahoga County. In response, the Cleveland Clinic engaged in a historic partnership with University Hospitals to offer free testing for <a href="Severe%20acute%20respiratory%20syndrome%20coronavirus%202">COVID-19</a>, to stop the spread of the virus in the metropolitan area and throughout the state.
Transportation.
Walkability.
In 2021, <a href="Walk%20Score">Walk Score</a> ranked Cleveland the seventeenth most walkable of the fifty largest cities in the United States., with a Walk Score of 57, a Transit Score of 45, and a Bike Score of 55 (out of a maximum of 100). Cleveland's most walkable areas can be found in the Downtown, Ohio City, Detroit–Shoreway, University Circle, and <a href="Buckeye%E2%80%93Shaker">Buckeye–Shaker Square</a> neighborhoods.
Urban transit systems.
Cleveland has a bus and <a href="urban%20rail%20transit">rail</a> <a href="public%20transport">mass transit</a> system operated by the Greater Cleveland Regional Transit Authority (RTA). The rail portion is officially called the <a href="RTA%20Rapid%20Transit">RTA Rapid Transit</a>, but local residents refer to it as "The Rapid". It consists of three <a href="rapid%20transit">light rail</a> lines, known as the <a href="Blue%20Line%20%28Cleveland%29">Blue</a>, <a href="Green%20Line%20%28Cleveland%29">Green</a>, and Waterfront Lines, and a <a href="heavy%20rail">heavy rail</a> line, the <a href="Red%20Line%20%28Cleveland%29">Red Line</a>. In 2008, RTA completed the HealthLine, a <a href="bus%20rapid%20transit">bus rapid transit</a> line, for which naming rights were purchased by the Cleveland Clinic and University Hospitals. It runs along Euclid Avenue from downtown through University Circle, ending at the <a href="Louis%20Stokes%20Station%20at%20Windermere">Louis Stokes Station at Windermere</a> in East Cleveland. RTA later opened a "BRT Light" line on the West Side along Clifton Blvd and the Shoreway. In 1968, Cleveland became the first city in the nation to have a direct rail transit connection linking the city's downtown to its major airport. In 2007, the <a href="American%20Public%20Transportation%20Association">American Public Transportation Association</a> named Cleveland's mass transit system the best in North America. Cleveland is the only metropolitan area in the Western Hemisphere with its rail rapid transit system having only one center-city area rapid transit station (Tower City-Public Square).
Private automobiles.
The city of Cleveland has a higher than average percentage of households without a car. In 2016, 23.7 percent of Cleveland households lacked a car, while the national average was 8.7 percent. Cleveland averaged 1.19 cars per household in 2016, compared to a national average of 1.8. Like other major cities, the urban density of Cleveland reduces the need for private vehicle ownership, though as jobs sprawl to urban edges across the United States, connectivity is becoming beyond the reach of public transit systems, including RTA.
Roads.
Cleveland's road system consists of numbered streets running roughly north–south, and named avenues, which run roughly east–west. The numbered streets are designated "east" or "west", depending on where they lie in relation to Ontario Street, which bisects Public Square. The numbered street system extends beyond the city limits into some suburbs on both the West and East Sides. The named avenues that lie both on the east side of the Cuyahoga River and west of Ontario Street receive a "west" designation on street signage. The two downtown avenues which span the Cuyahoga change names on the west side of the river. Superior Avenue becomes Detroit Avenue on the West Side, and Carnegie Avenue becomes Lorain Avenue. The bridges that make these connections are often called the <a href="Detroit%E2%80%93Superior%20Bridge">Detroit–Superior Bridge</a> and the <a href="Lorain%E2%80%93Carnegie%20Bridge">Lorain–Carnegie Bridge</a>.
Freeways.
Three two-digit <a href="Interstate%20highway">Interstate highway</a>s serve Cleveland directly. <a href="Interstate%2071">Interstate 71</a> begins just southwest of downtown and is the major route from downtown Cleveland to the airport. I-71 runs through the southwestern suburbs and eventually connects Cleveland with <a href="Columbus%2C%20Ohio">Columbus</a> and Cincinnati. <a href="Interstate%2077">Interstate 77</a> begins in downtown Cleveland and runs almost due south through the southern suburbs. I-77 sees the least traffic of the three interstates, although it does connect Cleveland to <a href="Akron%2C%20Ohio">Akron</a>. <a href="Interstate%2090">Interstate 90</a> connects the two sides of Cleveland, and is the northern terminus for both I-71 and I-77. Running due east–west through the West Side suburbs, I-90 turns northeast at the junction with and I-490, and is known as the Innerbelt through downtown. At the junction with the Shoreway, I-90 makes a 90-degree turn known in the area as <a href="Dead%20Man%27s%20Curve">Dead Man's Curve</a>, then continues northeast, entering <a href="Lake%20County%2C%20Ohio">Lake County</a> near the eastern split with <a href="Ohio%20State%20Route%202">Ohio State Route 2</a>. Cleveland is also served by two three-digit interstates, <a href="Interstate%20480%20%28Ohio%29">Interstate 480</a>, which enters Cleveland briefly at a few points and <a href="Interstate%20490%20%28Ohio%29">Interstate 490</a>, which connects I-77 with the junction of I-90 and I-71 just south of downtown. 
Two other limited-access highways serve Cleveland. The <a href="Cleveland%20Memorial%20Shoreway">Cleveland Memorial Shoreway</a> carries State Route 2 along its length, and at varying points also carries <a href="U.S.%20Route%206">US 6</a>, <a href="U.S.%20Route%2020">US 20</a> and I-90. The Jennings Freeway (<a href="Ohio%20State%20Route%20176">State Route 176</a>) connects I-71 just south of I-90 to I-480 near the suburbs of Parma and Brooklyn Heights. A third highway, the Berea Freeway (<a href="Ohio%20State%20Route%20237">State Route 237</a> in part), connects I-71 to the airport and forms part of the boundary between Cleveland and Brook Park.
Airports.
<a href="Cleveland%20Hopkins%20International%20Airport">Cleveland Hopkins International Airport</a> is the city's major airport and an <a href="international%20airport">international airport</a> that once served as a main <a href="airline%20hub">hub</a> for <a href="United%20Airlines">United Airlines</a> and <a href="Continental%20Airlines">Continental Airlines</a>. It holds the distinction of having the first airport-to-downtown rapid transit connection in North America, established in 1968. In 1930, the airport was the site of the first airfield lighting system and the first air traffic <a href="control%20tower">control tower</a>. Originally known as Cleveland Municipal Airport, it was the first municipally owned airport in the country. Cleveland Hopkins is a significant regional air freight hub hosting <a href="FedEx%20Express">FedEx Express</a>, <a href="UPS%20Airlines">UPS Airlines</a>, <a href="United%20States%20Postal%20Service">United States Postal Service</a>, and major commercial freight carriers.
In addition to Hopkins, Cleveland is served by <a href="Burke%20Lakefront%20Airport">Burke Lakefront Airport</a>, on the north shore of downtown between Lake Erie and the Shoreway. Burke is primarily a commuter and business airport.
Seaport.
The <a href="Port%20of%20Cleveland">Port of Cleveland</a>, at the Cuyahoga River's mouth, is a major bulk freight and container terminal on Lake Erie, receiving much of the raw materials used by the region's manufacturing industries. The Port of Cleveland is the only container port on the Great Lakes with bi-weekly container service between Cleveland and the <a href="Port%20of%20Antwerp">Port of</a> <a href="Antwerp">Antwerp</a> in <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a> on a <a href="Netherlands">Dutch</a> service called the "Cleveland-Europe Express." In addition to freight, the Port of Cleveland also welcomes regional and international tourists who pass through the city on <a href="Great%20Lakes%20passenger%20steamers">Great Lakes cruises</a>. Currently docking at Dock 28, just west of First Energy Stadium. The cruises currently run from mid-May through mid-October.
Railroads.
Cleveland has a long rich history as a major railroad hub in the United States. Today, <a href="Amtrak">Amtrak</a>, the national passenger rail system, provides service to Cleveland, via the "<a href="Capitol%20Limited%20%28Amtrak%29">Capitol Limited</a>" and "<a href="Lake%20Shore%20Limited">Lake Shore Limited</a>" routes, which stop at <a href="Cleveland%20Lakefront%20Station">Cleveland Lakefront Station</a>. Additionally, Cleveland hosts several inter-modal freight railroad terminals, for Norfolk Southern, CSX and several smaller companies. There have been several proposals for <a href="Cleveland%20commuter%20rail">commuter rail in Cleveland</a>, including a study into a Sandusky–Cleveland line. Cleveland was also identified as a hub for the now-suspended <a href="Ohio%20Hub">Ohio Hub</a> project, which would bring <a href="high-speed%20rail">high-speed rail</a> to Ohio.
Inter-city bus lines.
National <a href="intercity%20bus">intercity bus</a> service is provided at a <a href="Greyhound%20Lines">Greyhound</a> station, just behind the Playhouse Square theater district. <a href="Megabus%20%28North%20America%29">Megabus</a> provides service to Cleveland and has a stop at the Stephanie Tubbs Jones Transit Center on the east side of downtown. <a href="METRO%20RTA">Akron Metro</a>, <a href="Brunswick%20Transit%20Alternative">Brunswick Transit Alternative</a>, <a href="Laketran">Laketran</a>, <a href="Lorain%20County%20Transit">Lorain County Transit</a>, and <a href="Medina%20County%20Transit">Medina County Transit</a> provide connecting bus service to the Greater Cleveland Regional Transit Authority. <a href="Geauga%20County%20Transit">Geauga County Transit</a> and <a href="Portage%20Area%20Regional%20Transportation%20Authority">Portage Area Regional Transportation Authority (PARTA)</a> also offer connecting bus service in their neighboring areas.
Hyperloop proposal.
On February 15, 2018, <a href="Hyperloop%20Transportation%20Technologies">Hyperloop Transportation Technologies</a> announced that it had signed an agreement with the North Ohio Areawide Coordinating Agency and the <a href="Illinois%20Department%20of%20Transportation">Illinois Department of Transportation</a> to conduct a feasibility study for a planned Great Lakes <a href="Hyperloop">Hyperloop</a> system connecting Cleveland to Chicago in a half hour.
In June 2019, Congress approved $5 million to the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20Transportation">U.S. Department of Transportation</a> to explore safety standards for this project.
Sister cities and international relations.
As of , Cleveland maintains cultural, economic, and educational ties with 23 <a href="sister%20city">sister cities</a> around the world. It concluded its first sister city partnership with <a href="Lima">Lima</a>, <a href="Peru">Peru</a> in 1964. The Cleveland Council on World Affairs was established in 1923. In October 1915 at Cleveland's <a href="Bohemian%20National%20Hall%20%28Cleveland%2C%20Ohio%29">Bohemian National Hall</a>, Czech American and Slovak American representatives signed the Cleveland Agreement, a precursor to the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Agreement">Pittsburgh Agreement</a>, calling for the formation of a <a href="Czechoslovakia">joint Czech and Slovak state</a>. During the <a href="Cold%20War">Cold War</a>, Cleveland industrialist <a href="Cyrus%20S.%20Eaton">Cyrus S. Eaton</a>, an apprentice of John D. Rockefeller, played a significant role in promoting dialogue between the US and the <a href="Soviet%20Union">USSR</a>.
Cleveland is home to the <a href="List%20of%20diplomatic%20missions%20of%20Slovenia">Consulate General</a> of the <a href="Slovenia">Republic of Slovenia</a>, which, until Slovene independence in 1991, served as an official consulate for <a href="Josip%20Broz%20Tito">Tito</a>'s <a href="Socialist%20Federal%20Republic%20of%20Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>. In addition, the <a href="Jews%20and%20Judaism%20in%20Greater%20Cleveland">Jewish community of Greater Cleveland</a> maintains an unofficial supportive relationship with the State of <a href="Israel">Israel</a>. The Cleveland Clinic operates the <a href="Cleveland%20Clinic%20Abu%20Dhabi">Cleveland Clinic Abu Dhabi</a> hospital and a <a href="sports%20medicine">sports medicine</a> clinic in <a href="Toronto">Toronto</a>, and a Cleveland Clinic hospital campus in <a href="London">London</a> is scheduled to open in 2022.
